name: Smith, Stephen, MP
content: —These two bills were introduced into the House on Thursday last week. They are being debated here today, and they are listed for debate and passage in the Senate this week. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 and the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 are inextricably linked and, as a consequence, I have no objection to there being a cognate debate on these two bills. I make it clear at the outset, though, that Labor supports the legislative underpinning to develop and declare occupational health and safety codes and standards but opposes the abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. As a consequence of that, Labor supports the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 but opposes the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005. Labor adopts that position for the following reasons. Firstly, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission bill seeks to abolish the tripartite National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the NOHSC, and replace it with the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, the ASCC. Secondly, the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 seeks to enshrine in legislation the power of the Australian Safety and Compensation Council to develop occupational health and safety standards and codes once the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is abolished.Regrettably, Australia continues to have a poor record with respect to work related death, injury and illness. It is estimated that there are around 3,000 work related deaths in Australia each year. Work causes more fatalities than the national road toll. In 2002 road fatalities numbered more than 1,700 deaths. To think that Australia’s workplaces have a higher fatality incidence is truly appalling in modern Australia. When one breaks this down, the true gravity of the situation becomes apparent. Nearly 450 of those work related deaths—an average of nearly 10 per week—are the result of a traumatic incident at work, including work related road deaths, and a further 150 deaths occur while working Australians are travelling to or from work. Another 200 people who are bystanders die each year as a result of someone else’s work activity.In 1996 National Occupational Health and Safety Commission researchers arrived at a conservative estimate that at least 2,300 people died each year as a result of work related exposure to chemicals. This does not reflect the current extent of death from occupational disease. In the near future this figure may rise due to the expected increase in asbestos related deaths, a tragedy that for many decades has continued its macabre assault on working Australians, particularly through the Wittenoom disaster and the James Hardie disgrace. Australia has the highest incidence of asbestos related disease in the developed world. The incidence in Australia has been rising steeply since 1970, and it is estimated that the total number of asbestos related deaths will reach at least 40,000 and perhaps as many as 60,000 by 2020.More broadly, approximately 480,000 Australian employees experience a work related injury or illness each year. That translates to approximately 2.8 million Australians suffering from work related long-term health conditions. Each year there are around 140,000 compensated work related injuries resulting in an absence from work of one or more weeks. In comparison—excluding New South Wales, for which relevant data is not available—there are around 13,500 road accidents involving casualties each year in Australia.Turning to the compensation paid to workers suffering as a result of workplace injury, I regret to advise that only around 40 per cent of all employees who experience and suffer from a work related injury or illness receive some form of compensation. This of course has an enormous deleterious cost to our social and economic bottom line. It has been estimated that the cost to the economy exceeds $20 billion per annum, and it should be borne in mind that this figure of course does not take into account the social cost—the trauma and personal suffering of the victims and their families.Most responsibility for the implementation of occupational health and safety legislation, standards and codes of practice is exercised by state and territory governments. The Commonwealth’s involvement is through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council and, in its role as an employer, the Commonwealth Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission.In 1985, Labor established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. As a consequence, the commission has been in operation for about 20 years. The commission is not just the Commonwealth’s national body but Australia’s national body. It leads and coordinates the national effort to prevent workplace death, injury and disease in Australia.The commission is a tripartite statutory body with 18 members, including representatives of the Commonwealth, state and territory governments; and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which are the formal representatives of employers and employees. The commission is not a regulatory authority and thus neither makes nor enforces law. Largely the commission is responsible for producing key national standards as a model for laws in each Australian jurisdiction to help to achieve nationally consistent regulation; providing occupational health and safety statistics; ensuring that health and safety issues are included in training courses for employees in Australian industry; providing practical guidance to solve occupational health and safety problems and issues; and setting the national occupational health and safety research agenda.Because the commission does not make or implement occupational health and safety legislation, each jurisdiction may take up and amend commission documents to suit its own regulatory processes. This can result in differences in the way legislation is implemented in individual states and territories and has led in more recent times to arguments for the harmonisation of occupational health and safety legislation and regulation across and throughout the Commonwealth.The principal goal in establishing the commission in 1985 was to reduce the unacceptably high national record of occupational death, injury and illness. In doing so, the commission sought to develop an awareness of issues relevant to occupational health and safety matters among members of the community and facilitate public debate and discussion on such issues; to provide a forum in the public interest by which representatives of all Australian governments, employers and employees may consult and participate in developing and formulating policies and strategies relating to occupational health and safety matters; and to provide a national focus for activities relating to occupational health and safety matters.A key element of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is its tripartite nature. Tripartism is the most positive way of working within Australia’s constitutional framework. It ensures that the principal representative parties involved in occupational health and safety—namely governments, employers and employees—develop a close working relationship, an understanding of each other’s points of view and a commitment to common goals. Under the existing tripartite structure of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Commonwealth and state governments have clear and distinctive roles and responsibilities in occupational health and safety matters. The role of the Commonwealth is primarily one of coordination, facilitation and leadership.Since 1991, through its tripartite committees and working groups, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has declared seven priority national standards and codes of practice, covering a range of workplace health and safety hazards. While these have not always been adopted in a nationally consistent way in state and territory legislation, the very fact that priority national standards and codes of practice have been declared is testimony to the utility and success of the commission.In 1997, under the government’s direction, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission reduced its activity with regard to the development of national standards and codes of practice, although there are a range of hazards still to be addressed, including working hours, stress and bullying. The commission has been reluctant to take national action on these issues.Funding to the commission has been reduced since the Howard government came to power in 1996. In 1995-96, funding for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was $19.78 million. In 2004-05 it was $15.023 million. This has lead to the virtual cessation of National Occupational Health and Safety Commission financial support for important occupational health and safety research.Some workplace hazards have the potential to cause so much injury or disease that specific regulations or codes of practice are warranted. These regulations and codes, adopted under state and territory principal occupational health and safety acts, spell out the duties of particular groups of people in controlling the risks associated with specific hazards. Regulations are legally enforceable. Codes of practice provide advice on how to meet regulatory requirements. As such, codes are not legally enforceable but they can be used in courts as evidence that legal requirements have or have not been met.The national commission sets occupational health and safety standards for hazards common to many industries and workplaces across Australia. These standards do not become law until they are adopted as regulations in each of the states and territories. In March 2004 the Productivity Commission reported on its inquiry into national workers compensation and occupational health and safety frameworks. That report focused primarily on workers compensation rather than on occupational health and safety. The Productivity Commission found that ‘national uniformity in OH&S regulation should be a priority’—a reference to the harmonisation of approach to which I referred earlier.The Productivity Commission recommended that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission be reformed but not abolished. The Productivity Commission also recommended:clear specification of the objective of achieving uniform national occupational health and safety legislation and regulation in all jurisdictions in the NOHSC enabling legislation;agreement by all jurisdictions to adopt, without variation, the legislation and regulations proposed by NOHSC and approved by the Council;NOHSC have the ability to appoint advisory bodies, noting the importance of consulting with employers, unions and all jurisdictions;specified timetables for Council review of proposals from NOHSC, similar to those applying in relation to food standards — the process to be prescribed in the legislation; andfunding of NOHSC shared by the jurisdictions, together with a commitment to funding the research and data collection necessary to ensure the development of a best practice national occupational health and safety system.The Howard government’s response to the Productivity Commission’s inquiry is to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and replace it with the proposed Australian Safety and Compensation Council—the ASCC. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations announced in May 2004 that the government would maintain current funding for this body. In other words, the current funding of the commission would be applied to the proposed Safety and Compensation Council.Let me deal briefly with some provisions of the two bills. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 provides for the abolition of the commission through repealing the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. The bill also deals with the consequential and transitional matters arising from that repeal and from the enactment of the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Act 2005. Notably, the current standards and codes declared by the commission will be taken to have been declared by the ASCC, the body replacing the commission. As the minister indicated in his second reading speech, the bill ‘also preserves the effect of any public consultations that are under way and allows for these to be treated as if they had been undertaken by the new council’. The bill also transfers the National Occupational Health and Safety Strategy 2002-2012 and the associated business plan to the Australian Safety and Compensation Council.The Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 establishes the Australian Safety and Compensation Council by administrative or executive action. The Australian Safety and Compensation Council will be an advisory body only. The council is to be created executively rather than being underpinned through legislation. Labor is opposed to this downgrading of the status of the primary Commonwealth body responsible for leadership in occupational health and safety matters.The Australian Safety and Compensation Council’s functions will include the declaration of national standards and/or codes of practice relating to occupational health and safety. In addition, according to the minister, the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, as its title suggests, will:establish a national approach to ... workers compensation.As a result of representations from various stakeholders, the Howard government has agreed to empower the Australian Safety and Compensation Council through legislation with the ability to declare national standards or codes of practice. This is achieved through the bill and is a measure of the bill, which, obviously, Labor supports.Labor opposes the abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The Productivity Commission’s report did not recommend the abolition of the commission. It recommended adding to the commission’s role and specifying the objective of achieving uniform national occupational health and safety legislation and regulation in all jurisdictions within and throughout the Commonwealth in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act. Labor believes that replacing this statutory body with one that is merely administrative and executive is a downgrading of the important role the Commonwealth should play in leadership for occupational health and safety.In addition, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 provides a very detailed list of functions for the commission that includes: declaring national standards; formulating policies and strategies relating to occupational health and safety; making recommendations to action for state and territory governments; making recommendations in relation to compliance with international standards relating to occupational health and safety matters; reviewing laws and awards relating to occupational health and safety matters; evaluating policies, actions and laws made as a result of the commission’s work; research, inquiries and publications about occupational health and safety; and providing training and educational and promotional programs regarding occupational health and safety. In part for these reasons, Labor opposes the abolition of the commission.Given the government’s stated intention, as reflected by the bill, is to abolish the commission, Labor is pleased that the government has agreed to empower the new ASCC through legislation to be able to declare national standards or codes of practice. Labor is also pleased that the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 defines the ASCC as a tripartite body that represents the interests of governments, employers and employees. As a consequence Labor supports the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005.In addition, while Labor agrees that it is also important to address the recommendations the Productivity Commission made regarding workers compensation, to merely add this role to the body replacing the commission without providing additional resources means, in effect, that the government’s financial commitment to addressing occupational health and safety has been significantly reduced. Labor believes that ongoing national research into occupational health and safety, something severely compromised by the ongoing funding reductions to the commission in recent years, plays an ongoing important role in the identification and prevention of workplace death and injury in Australia.The proposal to abolish the tripartite, statutory National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and replace it with an administratively created advisory body, the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, substantially downgrades the Commonwealth’s participation and active role in occupational health and safety. Labor supports the development and implementation of national occupational health and safety standards and is committed to ensuring that there is a tripartite forum at the national level with employer, employee, industry and union, and state and territory government representation. In Labor’s very strong view this is best effected by the continuing role of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. As a consequence Labor opposes the repeal bill.

name: Barresi, Phillip, MP
content: —The Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 is required in order to ensure that the most important right for Australian workers is maintained—health and safety in the workplace. The bill will establish an Australian Safety and Compensation Council and will repeal the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. It will provide the legislative basis for declaring national occupational health and safety standards and codes of practice. The way this will happen is that through the bill we will ensure—and the government is committed to this—that there is a nationally consistent framework in place to manage safety. The bill will provide a platform for state and territory jurisdictions to adopt standards in the legislation and ensure that across Australia there are appropriate sanctions and penalties in place for failing to comply with certain workplace safety standards.The council will establish a national approach to safety and workers compensation and this national approach is very much needed. It is about 100 years since Federation. We now have eight different jurisdictions in this country, each with its own system of workplace relations and workplace safety. This government is committed to ensuring that, as much as possible, we have a uniform approach across Australia. Of course, we also recognise the responsibility and the obligations that the states have in this area of need. (Quorum formed)I am almost sure that the topic of safety and workers compensation has never before had such a large audience in this chamber, but I will resume what I was saying before the member for Chifley interrupted me. The bill arose following the Productivity Commission’s report National workers compensation and occupational health and safety frameworks of March 2004, which recommended that a number of changes take place in the area of occupational health and safety. We as a government have not accepted one of those recommendations. We decided to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. This will be abolished; however, as I mentioned earlier, we will be establishing the Australian Safety and Compensation Council in its place. Its primary function will be to recommend initiatives for the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council and promote national consistency in occupational health and safety and workers compensation.The Australian Safety and Compensation Council will be established administratively, with membership to be made up from representatives from the Commonwealth, state and territory governments, employers and employees. I know that a lot of stakeholders in this debate have welcomed this representation. I note that the opposition is keen on the council being established by legislation rather than through an administrative instrument. Of course this is not taking place. Nevertheless, the new council will have the ability to make recommendations to the ministerial council, and each of the various jurisdictions around Australia will have the ability to introduce in its own legislative program the recommendations that are brought forward.The process of declaring standards which are suitable for adoption in legislation by the jurisdictions assists in improving uniformity in OHS regulations in Australia. We are often told by employers that they have to operate within myriad different regulatory frameworks in Australia. Accordingly, the declaration of occupational health and safety standards and codes that can be adopted in state and territory legislation is an important step in reducing duplication and inconsistent regulation.For a few brief moments I want to discuss the role of the Australian Safety and Compensation Council. I know members on the other side will support it, as noted by the member for Perth. The ASCC will undertake the following key activities. It will develop a work plan for the implementation of the national framework for OH&S and workers compensation priorities, which will be endorsed by the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council. It will seek agreement by all jurisdictions to adopt and implement national OH&S standards declared by the council and endorsed by the ministerial council. It will provide for and encourage the states and territories to undertake a leadership role in the revision of existing national standards and the development of new standards as required. It will monitor the OH&S and workers compensation performance data at a national level, including the appropriate use of performance indicators. This is an issue which I am very much interested in. I will have more to say about it in another debate which will take place tomorrow afternoon.Furthermore, where appropriate the council will establish subcommittees. This recognises of the importance of consulting with relevant experts in the development of general and specific OH&S and workers compensation policy and regulation. Above all, it will have a research role and an evaluation role to ensure that we have best practice in the workplace.The government continues to be committed to improving occupational health and safety and workers compensation in this country. It is committed to ensure that the myriad regulatory regimes around Australia are brought in line and that there is consistency across the states.Our commitment to improving workers compensation is one that goes back a number of years. We made an offer a number of years ago to successive Victorian governments on two specific projects that would have allowed for a federal safety inspector to go on site. In return, additional funds would have been allocated to that state government for those projects. I understand that one of those was Federation Square and the other one was the MCG project. On both occasions the state government of the day rejected the offer and rejected the involvement of the Commonwealth government in having the right to enter those work sites.We are committed to this bill. We do not see this as an issue that needs to be politicised. I certainly welcome the opposition’s support of these bills. I note that they are not willing to support the repealing of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I think their concerns are ill-placed. The states will continue to have the ability to introduce, through their own legislation, the various codes of practice and conduct which will be recommended by the council to the ministerial council.
Speaker: N/A

name: O’Connor, Brendan, MP
content: —I am happy to rise to discuss the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 and the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005. Both of these bills are interrelated. It is true to say that, whilst Labor accepts that we can support the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill, it was made very clear by the member for Perth and by other commentators outside this place that we believe this is a downgrading of national occupational health and safety generally, particularly as it follows the proposed abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. If Labor were to have its way it would be looking to revitalise and strengthen the current commission.The current commission has undertaken very good work since its inception and it focuses on a very important area in the workplace. The one thing I think we share across the chamber in this place is an understanding of how important occupational health and safety policies are and how important it is that they are enforceable to ensure that we mitigate the capacity for Australian workers to be injured. If we prevent that likelihood we diminish the likelihood of fatality or injury generally in the workplace.The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has played its role in ensuring at least that there were efforts by the governments of the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to collaborate on matters of importance in this very important area of public policy. However, it is unfortunate that, instead of strengthening and building upon the importance of the commission, the government chooses to replace this tripartite body for an administrative council, which we believe would not have the teeth or the wherewithal to properly undertake the work that it will be asked to. We therefore see it as an unnecessary diminution of the national profile of OH&S.The commission itself managed to identify the fact that there are thousands of fatalities in Australia each year. Indeed, it received evidence from Access Economics that an estimate of 4,900 fatalities in Australia each year should be used as the approximate benchmark for fatalities in this country so that we can then work out ways to reduce that level of deaths in the workplace.The other very frightening statistic is the ABS statistic on work related injuries dated September 2000—some time ago now—which indicated that 477,800 persons experienced a work related injury or illness in the 12 months leading up to that date. In other words, between September 1999 and September 2000 almost 500,000 people had reported an injury of some sort, of whom 189,400 received workers compensation of some kind. That is a frightening proportion of the Australian work force—a frightening indictment on Australia’s incapacity, at least to date, to reduce injuries in the workplace. Therefore, it seems odd that the government would be putting less money into this area rather than more money.It is important to note that, with the election of the Howard government in 1996, the occupational health and safety budget at the Commonwealth level was reduced by between 30 and 40 per cent. I think that exemplified the government’s priorities and illustrated to those who paid attention that it did not consider that the Commonwealth had a particularly important role in this area.Whilst it is fair to say, as the member for Deakin indicated, that we have given some qualified support for the new council, it is not true to say that we support the entirety of these two bills or that we do not propose a preferred option, which would have ensured proper recognition for trade unions, employers and government in this legislation. It seems to me, and I think anyone who has represented employees in the workplace would say, that it is very important to bring all the parties relevant to the workplace together to consider ways to prevent injury. Therefore, to diminish one party’s role in that seems a very odd thing to do indeed. However, it is consistent with the government’s attitude towards employee organisations. It is a consistent thread that runs through all their legislation, not only industrial relations legislation—or, in this matter, occupational health and safety policies—but all areas of public policy.It seems now that it is almost a compulsory provision of any piece of legislation introduced by the government that there be some mechanism whereby collective bargaining will be diminished or threatened. We have seen that with education policies that tied Commonwealth funding to compelling employers to offer AWAs—even though that is not the intent of the Workplace Relations Act—and we have seen ministers outside the IR portfolio propose legislation that tries to reduce the likelihood of unions collectively bargaining. Unfortunately, even when it comes to something that I thought we had some sort of consensus on—namely, occupational health and safety—we see an unnecessary reduction in the role of trade unions in what would generally be seen as an area where we could get consensus. That is unfortunate. It is another example where the government’s blindness and its enmity towards employee organisations are such that it would rather play politics than have good public policy.As the shadow minister indicated, we support the second bill as it is important that there be a national body, but we believe that there is no need to remove the NOHSC. We note that the minor parties and Independents in the Senate have been on the record opposing the abolition of the NOHSC. Andrew Murray indicated his opposition to its abolition. Other spokespeople—people not from the Labor Party—have expressed concern about this unnecessary repeal of an important piece of legislation and the abolition of a relatively effective commission, when compared with what is being proposed. Having said that, I indicate, along with my colleagues, that whilst we have concerns about the way the government has decided to go down this path we are relieved that in the NOHSC’s place there will at least be somebody that will be able to bring together the parties nationally to talk about matters related to OH&S policies in order to bring some improvements to Australian workplaces and hopefully reduce the likelihood of injury or death.

name: Ferguson, Laurie, MP
content: —I was interested in the contribution of the member for Deakin. He had the temerity to commence with an allegation that the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 are ‘required for safety’. After listing the responsibilities of the new body, he finally assured all and sundry that any concerns were ‘ill placed’.I am afraid that I must have some doubts about his assurances, because this legislation has to be seen in the context of measures over the period of the current government. We have heard earlier references to the reduced expenditure that has been devoted to this area in the last decade. We now see a body being established which, as detailed by previous speakers, will essentially have less legislative strength and will be given responsibility in workers compensation without any consequent increase in the allocation of money towards that body. One can see a record of reduced money being devoted to the field, and in this new responsibility there will realistically be less expenditure again for safety.Previous speakers have cited the numbers of workplace deaths in this country, the most dramatic example being in the building industry. The figure, for which there is no debate, argument or contention, is that a worker a week dies in that industry. A paper produced for the parliament some time ago by the Parliamentary Library stated:The NOHSC have estimated that there are more than 2000 fatalities from workplace accidents and diseases per annum. This figure is only an estimate, because the long latency period of some diseases and the difficulty in relating some conditions to periods of work makes it difficult to quantify the precise number of deaths. However, the figure of around 2000 is taken to be an accurate estimate by NOHSC, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) and the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).Those deaths are estimated to cost the Australian economy $30 billion annually.We are talking about serious matters. On a broader front, we are talking about the individual devastation that occurs in families. In Sydney we have had very strong media coverage of the death of Joel Exner, a 16-year-old who fell 12 metres to his death from an Eastern Creek building; Anthony Hampson, a 42-year-old father of two who was badly injured after falling seven metres from a Gosford reroofing project; Dean McGoldrick, a 17-year-old who fell 12 metres from a Sydney building site; et cetera ad nauseam.It is interesting to note that previous speakers have talked about what is essentially part of this process, the attempt by this government to marginalise the unions and to take them out of the focus in industrial relations. That, of course, should be seen in the context of the ILO—another tripartite body; both sides are talking about tripartite bodies today in this debate. The ILO, which is internationally recognised and respected and participated in by Australian employers, noted in 2004 the central role of unions with regard to safety and determined that there was a correlation between union involvement in safety matters and low injuries, et cetera. It said that internationally sites were three times more likely to be safe where committees with union involvement were on the site, and it was two times more likely that there would be a management OH&S audit of those sites where unions were involved. As I said earlier, this is a serious matter at a personal level and with regard to national productivity and our overall financial situation in this country.People have spoken about asbestos. This is another area where we must have some concern and once again question the credibility of the government. We have witnessed the ACCC and the department of industrial relations harassing, following and pursuing councils in Sydney that have tried to put bans on the asbestos industry and its products. If they were really committed, as the member for Deakin says, to legislation to help workers, to protect people and to ensure safety we would not have measures by this government and its organisations to pursue those who seek to highlight the asbestos issue in this country—the dangers and the deaths that have resulted. They are estimated to be at least 53,000 by 2020.As the member for an electorate which is very close to the major manufacturer in Sydney, James Hardie, and also to the previous manufacturer, Wunderlich, owned by CSR, I am very aware of these issues. Those employers tended historically to employ the latest strand of migration to this country, the new wave of migrant labourers that occurred. In the period I was associated with the union that had coverage in this field, the Lebanese in particular were prevalent. In our area we have not only the possibility of a very high prevalence of deaths and serious illness over the next decade but also the reality of masses of illegal dumps by James Hardie in the region. The numbers are thought to be quite high.Can we have the confidence the member for Deakin puts to us that all our doubts as to the government’s gestures and intentions should be dismissed and that we can be assured that the government really intends to do something? I say not because, as I said with regard to asbestos, we see them pursuing those who seek to publicise and dramatise this industry and its failings; and we see the expenditure they have devoted to occupational health and safety in this country. Also, they really got out of bed very early on one particular legislative endeavour over the last few years and that was to override the ACT legislation on industrial manslaughter. Once again, as the previous government speaker, the member for Deakin, said, that is not very active on all of the recommendations of the ACCC—they have decided not to follow one or two of those—but very active in intervening to make sure that workers in the ACT are not going to be protected by a bill which said that an employer or a senior officer could have fines of up to $5 million and 25 years in jail if they were perceived to have played a major role by their negligence in regard to an employer.The other thing that leads me to have some doubts about the government’s real intentions to increase safety in the interests of workers in the industry is the performance of the infamous Cole commission into the building industry. The government did say that the minister should table the annual NOHSC report on progress in implementing the NOHSC occupational health and safety strategy for 2002-12. However, after hearing a plethora of complaints about the role of the CFMEU in this industry on what would seem to many of us to be a very serious issue, occupational health and safety—with one death a week in this industry—the commission ‘proposed to address this critical issue’—they did say a few nice words on the way through—‘other than through the public hearing process’.It was decided that there would be a conflab and some discussion papers. That of course contrasted with a welter of witnesses coming forward, with tens of millions of dollars devoted to that inquiry and with the threat of court proceedings, most of which came to nothing—$60 million worth of taxpayers’ money spent on supposedly a good purpose came to no significant prosecutions. As I say, I have grave doubts that we are going to get the protection of people in this country through this legislation.In general we have a government which has sought constantly to override legislation aimed at introducing measures against the pursuit of people responsible for deaths in industry. We witness a government which has reduced expenditure on safety in this country and the process of this committee itself. We are assured it is going to be tripartite and that it is going to have some role. But, given its performance over the period since 1985 when it was established to set standards, do analysis, come up with training proposals, produce statistics and propose national measures that would be taken up by the various states, one must have grave doubts that the real intention of this government is to accomplish anything worth while for workers in this field.Rather than come up with these kinds of measures which seek to diminish and deride the need for occupational health and safety in this country the government should be setting about establishing a proper national database, ensuring that the safety records of particular companies are kept, ensuring that licensing in an industry should become a matter for contractors and subcontractors with poor records, looking at a safety plan being provided on all projects—the successful applicant giving this to the union delegates afterwards to ensure it is adhered to, and looking at government contracts and adherence to safety standards by companies that are contracted. As I said earlier, the government should be looking at industrial manslaughter and at the annual inspection of various contracts and measures of adequate financial deterrence.In conclusion, there were some nice words said by the opposition about these measures, some of which are not of concern. Clearly the broader agenda of this government is to decrease the role of workers in safety issues on sites around the country, to ensure that there are not tougher measures against deaths on sites and to diminish the overall emphasis in this country on occupational health and safety.Question agreed to.Bill read a second time.
