name: Emerson, Craig, MP
content: —The Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005 before us tonight does provide some welcome relief in funding for universities but it is very partial relief. It astonishes me that, on the very day when the government has announced that it will now seek an immigration program that has not been seen since the era of the ten pound pom, we are debating policies of a government that has been presiding over enormous skill shortages. Skill shortages do not happen overnight. There is evidence of the emergence of skill shortages going back almost a decade. In nine long years this government has done very little to anticipate and ease the skill shortages with which this country is now afflicted. This legislation makes a very small contribution to it but I have to categorise it as being too little, too late.I do in fact support the notion of a larger immigration program and one that is based on skills, but this should be a complement to domestic skills formation rather than a substitute. Yet after nine long years, this government has allowed the skills crisis to develop to the point where it has had to adopt almost emergency measures in the form of the announcements that have been made in the last day or so. It bemuses me that the present Minister for Education, Science and Training has been so unsuccessful in gaining support of the Prime Minister and his cabinet colleagues for extra government funding for our universities. The results of this sloth and inactivity are there for all to see.We know that there is enormous value in increasing the proportion of high school leavers who go on to complete university. I will cite some of the relevant indicators: Australian university graduates earn at least 50 per cent more than high school completers and 70 per cent more than high school drop-outs. So even the private benefits from a university education are very large—a 70 per cent increase in earnings, on average, compared with high school drop-outs.But that is not to count the wider social benefits—the benefits to the nation as a whole—which, in economic jargon, are called ‘spill-over benefits’. They are very large indeed. Plenty of empirical work has been done on this. Indeed, the nurturing of intellect and the acquisition of skills is by far the most potent source of productivity growth in the modern world. That point has been demonstrated by empirical work conducted by the OECD. Now knowledge and skills arguably stand alone as the only source of comparative advantage in the 21st century. This point was made in 1996 by Lester Thurow. The value of investing in skills through higher education is that it offers the double benefit of not only raising productivity but also lifting lifetime work force participation rates. I refer to a study by Access Economics that has just been documented in a publication released by the Business Council of Australia. In that report Access Economics says:Education is increasingly becoming the ‘engine room’ of modern economies. If we get this part of the economy right, most other things ought to fall in place (or be better placed), because increased investment in education boosts both productivity and participation.The truth is that the Whitlam government opened the doors of the nation’s universities to the children of working Australians—to average Australians and underprivileged Australians. The Hawke and Keating governments expanded access to a university education, equipping young people with the skills to be able to go on to a university education, through a doubling of the proportion of young people who completed year 12 from 36 per cent to well in excess of 70 per cent. Equipping young people to go on to university was a great contribution to our nation’s future, but the Hawke and Keating governments did more than that. Through the introduction of HECS, the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, funding coming from the future earnings of the students themselves was used to expand greatly the number of university places, thereby opening up access to our universities by people who otherwise could not afford it.The coalition government, however, is reversing all this. It is making access to a university education a lot harder for all except the privileged. Both the increased rationing of places according to the capacity to pay full fees and the prospect of massive HECS debts for those fortunate enough to gain a HECS place are creating circumstances where the number of Australians going on to university has now fallen for only the second time in the last 50 years. This is a terrible tragedy. During the 1980s and early 1990s, when there was great debate and great activity on an economic reform program for Australia, it was often said that to stand still in the Asia-Pacific region is to fall behind. We needed to continue with reform and to invest in education, in knowledge and in research and development in order just to hold our place among other countries in the region and in the wider world. That was the accepted wisdom at the time, but it is not the wisdom of the Howard government. In relation to higher education, the Howard government at present is not only standing still but is falling behind. If to stand still is to fall behind, then let us think for a moment of the consequences of going backwards.In this the Asian century, the countries of our region are investing heavily in higher education—to the point where India alone is producing six million university graduates a year, two million of whom are English speaking; and China is producing an estimated 3.4 million university graduates a year. Australia, in contrast, is producing 215,000 university graduates a year. It is obvious that we cannot match the absolute numbers of university graduates of India or of China; but, in this the Asian century, we certainly need to take a great leap forward in the proportion of our young people who go on to a university education.In the 1960s, using the best available statistics—which sadly are scant—the proportion of young people going on to university was about eight per cent. Through the 1980s, with the introduction of HECS and the expansion of university places, it had built up and it is now around 30 per cent. In my book, 30 per cent of young people going on to university is a grossly inadequate proportion. If we are to be successful in this the Asian century, if we are to compete effectively against China, India and other emerging countries in our region, we must lift the proportion of young people who are going on to university—because, as Lester Thurow has observed, knowledge and skills stand alone as the determinants of comparative advantage and the wealth of nations in the 21st century.But what is the Australian experience with skills formation? It is an indictment. A Productivity Commission review of the Australian evidence concludes that the increase in average schooling in the working age population slowed from 0.5 a year in the 1980s to 0.2 a year in the 1990s. The Productivity Commission concludes:... there appears to have been no significant acceleration in work force skills in the 1990s. In fact, the evidence shows a faster increase in skills in the 1980s.So when Australia had genuinely entered the productivity race and was reforming the economy, that was a great period. But, to accelerate that productivity growth, we needed at the same time to continue through the 1990s and the early 21st century the sorts of investment in education that had occurred in the 1980s under the previous Labor government. Sadly, that did not happen and the Productivity Commission has concluded that there was a deceleration.The Productivity Commission is not alone. The conclusions have been confirmed by the OECD’s work, which indicates that skill upgrading made no contribution to Australian productivity growth between 1990 and 2000. Drawing this work together, Saul Eslake asks:So why has education apparently not made any discernible contribution to the improvement in Australia’s economic performance over the past decade? The answer, unfortunately, seems to be that there has not been any discernible improvement in Australia’s educational outcomes—at least insofar as they impact on productivity growth during this period.I have to report that Australia ranks a lowly 20th out of 30 OECD countries in the share of 15- to 19-year-olds enrolled in postcompulsory secondary education. So the story is a tragic one; it is a story of tragically wasted opportunity.Again, Australia stands alone among OECD countries on another score. The privately funded share of education spending has risen more quickly in Australia since 1995 than in any other OECD country. We have been unique amongst OECD countries in failing to increase public funding commensurately with increased private funding. By that, the OECD means that private funding has increased more rapidly in Australia than in any other country and that public funding has fallen behind. In other countries both private and public funding have risen together so that obviously the total number of young people who could go on to higher education has been increasing. But that is not the case in Australia, and it is an indictment of this government.The fundamental problem—and it goes to the provisions of this bill—is that this government has failed to index adequately the Commonwealth grants that go to our universities. There are varying estimates of the total funds that the universities have missed out on as a result of the government’s unwillingness to index those payments, but essentially the government’s philosophy is that university education is a private matter and that nearly all additions to the funding of universities must therefore come from the private sector. The government does not recognise, does not acknowledge the wider benefits to the community of a university education.The consequence is plain: Australia stands out amongst OECD countries as the one country where increases in private spending on education have substituted for, rather than complemented, extra public spending. I will quote again:In fact, many OECD countries with highest growth in private spending have also shown the highest growth in public funding of education. This indicates that increasing private spending on tertiary education tends to complement, rather than replace, public investment. The main exception to this is Australia, where the shift towards private expenditure at tertiary level has been accompanied by a fall in the level of public expenditure in real terms.So there we are. Australia is unique amongst the OECD at a time when we know—when all the evidence shows—that skills formation is the most powerful contributor to productivity growth and therefore prosperity and the wealth of nations. The Australian government stands alone amongst OECD countries in shifting funding towards private expenditure at the tertiary level and reducing the level of public expenditure in real terms.I pick up where I began and ask the question rhetorically: why has this Minister for Education, Science and Training been so spectacularly unsuccessful in gaining the support of the Prime Minister and of his colleagues for increased support for our universities at this incredibly important period in Australia’s development? The answer has to be, for starters, that the Treasurer does not want to see the minister for education succeeding to the same extent that he has seen his other rival, the Minister for Health and Ageing, succeed in getting a lot of money for Medicare before the last election. So, in this rivalry for the prospective future leadership of the Liberal Party, it is not only the minister for education who is missing out—and I will not be weeping crocodile tears for him—but also the young people of Australia.It is my duty to report a conversation in which the minister for education was involved. A matter of privilege was reported in this parliament just a few days ago by the member for Eden-Monaro in relation to the falsification of documents. I reckon this one deserves a bit of scrutiny, too, because it is surely inconceivable that the education minister could have engaged in the dialogue to which I am about to refer. When the minister announced that the government would be allowing universities to apply full fees to up to 35 per cent of Australian students, he seemed pretty confident that he would be able to remove a cap on the amount of fees that could be covered by the FEE-HELP funding support program. FEE-HELP is similar in design to HECS, but the problem is that FEE-HELP is capped at $50,000. We will recall that, many times before the last election, the Prime Minister was saying that there would be no $100,000 university fees under his government. Well, many scores of university courses now charge fees well in excess of $100,000, so that is yet another broken promise on the part of the Prime Minister.The minister for education was interviewed on the John Faine program on 4 August. John Faine asked:The man responsible for introducing student loans says the way the system is evolving and where you are taking it is only going to help rich students, students from rich families, is he right?The minister replied:Well in fact Professor Chapman—the architect of the HECS program—is right, but the interpretation of what he is saying is in fact a little bit incorrect. Professor Chapman is one of the people who designed the HECS program and what he is referring to in this context Jon are the full fee paying students, these are the Australian students.Professor Chapman was indeed referring to those full fee paying students—up to 35 per cent of students now. The minister then went on to say:Well in fact we have got 784 courses in Australian unis which charge or offer full fee paying places to Australians, we have got about 16 of those courses that have fees of around $100,000 or more, needless to say veterinary science, dentistry and so on.I would just point out that that number has greatly increased since this interview on 4 August. John Faine then asked:Medicine?The minister replied:Well Medicine not yet, but that’s coming in, and we know that Notre Dame will be about $125,000 and we have heard that Melbourne will be about $200,000.The minister seems very worried about this, but it is his legislation that is allowing this to happen. John Faine said to him:Now there is no way that an ordinary Australian family can afford to put a kid through one of those courses is there?The minister replied:Well in fact you are right.So here is the minister saying that John Faine and Professor Chapman are right. The reality is that the minister was confident that he would be able to get that cap removed from FEE-HELP. He went back to cabinet and he got rolled. The result is that here we are in this the 21st century—the Asian century, where we will need to compete against these countries—and the government has increased the number of full fee paying Australian places to up to 35 per cent and it has allowed universities to increase HECS by up to 25 per cent. It is pricing a university education out of the reach of the sons of daughters of the working people of this country. This legislation gives me the opportunity to brand this minister a complete failure and to call as very urgent the need for fundamental reform of our higher education system.
debateinfo: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (2005 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Bartlett, Kerry, MP
content: —It is rather disappointing that the member for Rankin, in speaking on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005, which largely involves committing extra funding to James Cook University and the University of Western Sydney, used the opportunity to push his own hobbyhorse and in a distorted way represent his views about private funding versus public funding for universities. I must point out in response to the member for Rankin just a couple of critical points that he omitted. In decrying, as he did, the cocontribution through the HECS scheme of students at university he totally ignored the fact that it was a Labor government in the mid-1980s that introduced the HECS fee system on the principle that there was a role for students who would benefit from a university education to contribute something towards their own education.He also omitted to say that the HECS increases for those universities which have decided to increase HECS funding over the last couple of years are really only marginal increases and that, even for those courses and those universities where a funding increase has been agreed to, it will still only involve students increasing their contribution to the cost of a university education from 26 per cent to 28 per cent. In other words, taxpayers will still be meeting 72 per cent of the cost of the average university education. This is an increase from 26 per cent to 28 per cent or a decrease in the taxpayer contribution from 74 per cent to 72 per cent—hardly the draconian changes that the member for Rankin was indicating.Another two points need to be made in response to the member for Rankin before I turn to the legislation before us. Firstly, in that change the government substantially increased the threshold at which university students would commence repaying their HECS debt from $24,365 to a threshold last year of $35,000 and a threshold in July this year of $36,814. Rather than being able to argue, as the member for Rankin has, that somehow university education is being priced out of the realms of possibility for the ordinary worker, the very substantial rise in the threshold at which repayment starts actually does make it a lot more affordable for average university students. They can earn a whole lot more after university graduation before they need to start repaying their HECS debt.The other point that needs to be made is that the member for Rankin and many others on the other side keep referring to these full fee paying places and talking about $100,000 degrees and so on as though somehow this means that ordinary people are being precluded or excluded from university. The critical point that he again conveniently omitted is this: no university is able to impose full fee paying places at the expense of taxpayer or HECS funded places. They are in addition to—over and above—the increased HECS places. They are not in any way precluding Australian students from taking up the increased number of university places under the HECS system.The other point that he omits is that the Labor Party is quite happy to continue to support full fee paying places for overseas students but would want to prevent Australian students accessing the same right that overseas students have. For the life of me I cannot understand the double standards that Labor wants to apply here: it is okay for students from overseas countries to come and pay to access an Australian university education but not for an Australian student who might have just missed out on a HECS place to avail themselves of the same opportunity. I am stunned that Labor wants to provide an opportunity for students from overseas that they want to prevent being made available to Australian students.Let me turn to the legislation. The technical details of this legislation really are quite straightforward. They are, despite the tangential offering from the member for Rankin, non-controversial, but the implications and the impact of this legislation are quite significant in three ways. Firstly, this legislation is a clear demonstration of this government honouring its election commitments. The amendments to the Higher Education Support Act 2003 are amendments for two purposes that were promised prior to last year’s election. The first is to provide 100 new places in veterinary science and tropical agriculture at James Cook University. These places will commence in 2006 and will rise to 274 places by 2009. This was a commitment of $13.9 million that was made last year that is now being delivered. These extra places will provide veterinary science places for veterinarians specialising in the prevention and early detection of animal diseases that are prevalent in tropical areas, so they will be a great boost to the tropical part of Northern Queensland. As well as this, these places will provide for education in aspects of tropical agriculture, including the agriculture that involves sugarcane production—again, of direct relevance to the local community. Here again the government is honouring its election commitments.The second aspect of this bill is the commitment of funding of $25 million over the next three years to improve infrastructure at the University of Western Sydney. I for one, along with a number of my colleagues—and I notice the member for Macarthur at the table there—have been pushing for years for extra funding for infrastructure and so on for the University of Western Sydney. Last year the Prime Minister made a commitment that we would deliver extra funding for infrastructure for the University of Western Sydney. This legislation delivers on that commitment. It delivers an extra $25 million. That includes $7 million for a new library at the Penrith campus. It delivers $2 million for upgraded research and teaching facilities at the Hawkesbury campus. It delivers $7 million for a medical faculty at the UWS Campbelltown campus—that is in addition to $18 million already budgeted. It includes $9 million for a new teaching building at the Parramatta campus. So that is $25 million for the University of Western Sydney, directly delivering on those election commitments that were made last year. We said we would deliver, and here we are delivering.This funding allocation involves substantial tangible improvements for these two universities, further evidence of the government’s commitment to higher education. We had the member for Rankin somehow talking about a reduction in funding for universities, a government abrogating their responsibility. He very conveniently ignored the fact that we had an allocation of an extra $2.6 billion over five years for higher education or an extra $6.9 billion over 10 years for education in last year’s budget and a record $7.8 billion in this year’s budget for higher education. This is a substantial commitment to higher education, both broadly and also, I am pleased to say, in the area of Western Sydney.I was interested to hear the shadow spokesperson for education, the member for Jagajaga, speaking on this bill last week. What she was saying seemed to be supporting these funding commitments. It was quite interesting, though, to compare that with what she had to say last year. When the government made these election commitments last year, in this place the member for Jagajaga dismissed this $25 million for the University of Western Sydney and the $13.9 million for James Cook University as ‘cynical election sweeteners’, ‘little sweeteners’ and ‘just a drop in the ocean’.I can assure the member for Jagajaga that the $25 million for the University of Western Sydney is not just a ‘little sweetener’. It is not ‘just a drop in the ocean’. The people of Western Sydney greatly appreciate the $25 million that will improve facilities at our university, and I am sure the people of North Queensland greatly appreciate that extra funding for James Cook University as well. I am appalled that the member for Jagajaga could have dismissed them as ‘just a drop in the ocean’. This is very significant funding for two very important regional universities.The money committed to the University of Western Sydney will help meet the needs of a university that is vital to this region of Sydney. This is an area of really substantial need. We have 1.8 million people in Western Sydney, rising by something like 50,000 people a year, with large housing projects planned. The population will continue to increase in years to come. Yet, in educational terms, over the decades the Western Sydney region has not been catered for as well as other regions of Sydney. We have a lot of young people with aspirations for improved education, hungry for education and eager to get on in life, yet significantly, compared to other regions of Sydney, the educational attainment in decades past has not been as good. For instance, only 10.5 per cent of the population of Western Sydney is tertiary trained, compared to an overall average of about 21 per cent for Sydney—a much lower participation rate. So I am pleased to see that the government is demonstrating its commitment to building higher education in Western Sydney. For instance, in this year’s budget we had $235.7 million committed to the University of Western Sydney. That is an increase of $15.3 million or 6.9 per cent over last year. This year there were 18,267 fully funded undergraduate places, up by 2,747 since 1996. So I am delighted to see this as yet another demonstration of this government’s commitment to the University of Western Sydney.I want to refer to two specific aspects of this legislation. The whole of the $25 million will be a significant boost for Western Sydney, but two aspects are of particular interest to me. One is the $2 million for research and teaching infrastructure at the Hawkesbury campus. This will include a state-of-the-art confocal multiphoton fluorescence microscope system, which will be the only one in Australia. It will put applied science research at the University of Western Sydney Hawkesbury campus at the forefront of some of this research in Australia.The University of Western Sydney Hawkesbury campus has been doing it tough for a number of years—the declining interest in agriculture has been part of the reason for that—but in the last three or four years I have been greatly encouraged to see the numbers rebuilding there. We are one of the leaders in horticulture. We have seen exciting growth in recent years in aspects of applied science, including environmental science and forensic science. We have seen a growth in nursing places, and I want to see that continue. This $2 million for the state-of-the-art research microscope system at UWS Hawkesbury campus will certainly continue to boost its profile.The second feature I want to focus on is the extra $7 million allocated for the medical school for the University of Western Sydney. I make the point again that this $7 million is in addition to $18 million already committed, so this brings the Australian government’s commitment to the UWS medical school to $25 million. Starting in 2007, this will mean 80 places for medicine, and that will pipeline out to 320 places by 2010. I note that last year the member for Jagajaga criticised the government for committing money for infrastructure but not for places. Again, the member for Jagajaga was wrong. We have a commitment for 80 places to start in 2007, and up to 320 places will be in place by 2010.The building and commencement of a medical school for Western Sydney will be a great boost to this area for two reasons. The first reason is educational. Young people living in Western Sydney who want to study medicine and who have the ability to study medicine will no longer have to spend three to four hours a day travelling from, say, the Blue Mountains or Kurrajong in my electorate of Macquarie into the University of Sydney or the University of New South Wales. They will now be able to study medicine in Western Sydney. This will be of tremendous benefit educationally.More broadly, the establishment of a medical school in Western Sydney will be a great boost for medicine and for health services in Western Sydney generally. Western Sydney does suffer. Our doctor-patient ratio is much lower than it is for most of Sydney. In Western Sydney in my electorate the doctor-patient ratio is one to 1,800, whereas in central Sydney it is one to 825, so we do need to attract GPs to Western Sydney. The government has undertaken a number of other initiatives that are starting to have an impact, and I greatly appreciate those. But this facility will also help to attract doctors to the area, for a couple of reasons.Firstly, some of the places will be bonded places. Students will be allocated places to study medicine at UWS on the condition that they practise for a certain time in Western Sydney. That will directly add to the supply of GPs in the area. Secondly, students from elsewhere who come to study at UWS will realise that it is a great place to live. They will put down roots, they will make connections, they will form friendships in the area and they will decide to settle in the area and practise in Western Sydney. So the establishment of a medical faculty there will boost the number of doctors practising in Western Sydney. This legislation is really going to be of significant benefit—and in your electorate of Blaxland as well, Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton. It will benefit all of those who live and work in Western Sydney.In summing up, I will make one other point. It is a disappointment to me that the New South Wales state government are not willing to help in this enterprise. When the idea of a medical faculty for UWS was first raised, the then Premier Mr Carr said: ‘Yes, this is a good idea. UWS needs a medical faculty.’ The Australian government have now committed $25 million. There is $25 million on the table. But what do we have from the New South Wales government? No commitment of cash to help, and we really need it. The challenge is there for the New South Wales government. If they are serious about the benefits that a medical school will bring to Western Sydney, they need to match the Australian government’s contribution.Even worse than the state government’s neglect of UWS is its iniquitous payroll tax regime, which takes money out of UWS. I have made the point before that every year the state Labor government takes around $10 million out of the coffers of the University of Western Sydney via its payroll tax system. This year we have the Australian government committing some $235 million to the University of Western Sydney and we have the state government saying: ‘Thank you very much. I’ll take $10 million of that out and put it into state general revenue.’ If the New South Wales government were really committed to the University of Western Sydney, it would be ending that payroll tax regime and supporting the University of Western Sydney in the same way that the Australian government is.I am pleased to support this legislation. It brings a significant amount of extra money to the University of Western Sydney. It delivers on a key election commitment to the people of Western Sydney and it will bring substantial benefits to the people of Western Sydney, as well as to the people of North Queensland through its commitment to the James Cook University.
debateinfo: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (2005 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Hayes, Chris, MP
content: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the extension of funding, particularly in relation to the University of Western Sydney. I wish to speak on the extension of funding for the new medical school at Campbelltown. While I wholeheartedly support the development of a medical school at the Campbelltown campus, I do have some concerns. A $7 million injection of funds into the development of the university’s medical school is a welcome investment in the south-west of Sydney. It is an investment which I would suggest is well overdue. Although this commitment does not match the one that Labor took to the last election, clearly Labor’s commitment of some $43 million has made the government realise that the medical school is something that is needed for our region.The Minister for Education, Science and Training noted in his second reading speech:The ... medical school will enhance and improve the teaching hospital capacity and the delivery of health and medical services in western and south-western Sydney. It will also provide opportunities for local students to study medicine in their own region.Might I suggest that the development of this medical school is on track. I am pleased to note that in the week before last the Macarthur Advertiser reported that the Australian Medical Council had approved the first stage of the university’s medical school, which gives the university the go-ahead to implement their medical program. The Advertiser went on to report that over the coming months the university will develop detailed plans, outlining such matters as curricula, staffing facilities, research and clinical placements. It is expected that this second stage of the process will be submitted to the Australian Medical Council for its consideration sometime in February next year.I would like to take this opportunity to commend the work of the dean of the medical school, Professor Neville Yeomans, and the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Sydney, Professor Janice Reid, for their hard work in getting the school to this point. They should be recognised for and congratulated on their efforts.The development of a local, high-quality medical school and medical training infrastructure is extremely important to south-west Sydney and Western Sydney because our region needs more doctors. As a young and rapidly growing community, the ability to find affordable and accessible medical services is essential. In my electorate alone, there are more than 20,000 families with dependent children. Although the medical school will be a welcome addition to the medical infrastructure in the south-west, it is a medium-term proposition and the government continues to fail to address the short-term needs of this community.In 2004, it was estimated that Australia needed up to 3,000 more GPs. Consider that in conjunction with the report by the Medical Observer last year which indicated that 57 per cent of those GPs surveyed believed that general practice was not a good career choice for students. Having regard to that statistic, I hope the government intends to integrate its policy approaches to medical training and workplace planning. The Campbelltown campus will not produce a fully qualified doctor until 2012. While its contribution over the longer period is likely to be immense, families in my electorate and throughout the south-west of Sydney need the government to do more right now to increase the supply of doctors and affordable and accessible health services within this region.At the outset, I mentioned that I had some concerns. My concerns do not directly relate to the appropriation of $7 million to the university but rather to the notion that this will mean that local students can automatically access the medical school. I understand that all students will have that access, subject to meeting the relevant education standards. I also understand that prospective students will be subject to a battery of aptitude tests and interviews. My concern is that, due to the decade of neglect of tertiary education under this government, local students may be priced out of the education market. I am concerned that, because of the quite draconian changes to student income support over the last decade, many students and their families are placed under considerable financial pressure when they undertake university studies.Often parents contact my office to seek some insight into why this government is making it even more difficult for their children to get a university education by subjecting them to an income test to receive the youth allowance. The income test is not based on the income of the student but on the income of the supporting parents. Labor took to the last election its policy aimed at improving income support for students while they study. I note that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, in its submission to the 2005 Commonwealth budget, called on the federal government to improve income support for students but, alas, the government has not acted on that submission.I am concerned that the belief behind the strong community support for the medical school, which is predicated on the basis that the sons and daughters in greater Western Sydney will have access to it, will not necessarily translate into reality. In my electorate, the 2001 census reported that only six per cent of the people had attained a bachelor degree or higher. Many of those people were among the first in their families to receive a university education, because a university education was not placed beyond their reach. The importance of having a high-quality, local university is not lost on my constituents.When I was studying, I would have appreciated the opportunity to attend a local school rather than attending lectures in Sydney and making that late-night trek home. To some extent, for people who studied in those days—and particularly for those who lived in Campbelltown—it was half dangerous. It was not dangerous in respect of personal security but, in those days, you did not catch the normal suburban train home to Campbelltown. At that hour of the night, you lined up to catch the Cooma Mail. You could not afford to get too comfortable on that train because, as the member for Macarthur will know, if you missed Campbelltown, you were likely to end up in the Southern Highlands or somewhere between there and Goulburn. The students who follow us will at least not have to brave the ventures of part-time study in Sydney and travel home to Campbelltown.Recently I spoke to Dr Andrew McDonald, the Director of Paediatrics at Macarthur Health Services. He is right behind the medical school and is looking forward to integrating the local hospital network with the school. He knows the quality of health care professionals in our area and is confident that the medical school, with the support of the region’s hospitals, will produce high-quality doctors. While no-one can ever be certain that locating a medical school in Western Sydney will produce more doctors who live and work in the region, I am heartened by the findings of a number of studies that in fact suggest as much. The evidence suggests that students from rural and regional backgrounds often end up practising in rural or regional areas. It is my understanding that the likelihood of this occurring is heightened when these students have the opportunity to study in or near the areas which they are from. I am confident, with the support of the local hospitals, with the support of high-quality health care professionals such as Dr McDonald and his team, who are currently practising in our area, and with the support of the local community, that once students have the opportunity to experience all that our region has to offer they may make the decision to stay.I hope it is the case that students from the south-west and from Western Sydney do get the opportunity to study at this medical school, because they already know what a great place the region is and what a great place it is to raise a family. I would be reasonably confident that the majority of graduates who come through that infrastructure would continue to see some purpose in living and practising within our region. I hope the funding in conjunction with the government’s tertiary education policies will not mean that the first generation of people from this region to have reasonable access to a university education will be the last. I hope that the medical school will act as an inspiration for the local students to study hard in the knowledge that they could end up studying at a fantastic institution that is just down the road from their families and their long-established personal support networks.The University of Western Sydney medical school was suggested by a Labor Premier and later adopted by this government, and as a Labor member I have to say that I am extremely proud to support it. The school has been supported by the Labor state government, contrary to the suggestion from the member for Macquarie, as the state government intends to provide a site adjacent to or within the Liverpool Hospital grounds for the development of support facilities. The University of Western Sydney is a fine institution and I support its aim to develop a distinctive and innovative school that will support and integrate with our local community. I look forward to the extension of the Campbelltown campus of the university and the development of the medical school itself.Not long ago the university launched a Bachelor of Laws program. I can report that this has proven to be a success, with many graduates who have studied at the campus continuing their association with the region by living and working there. I noted recently on the Whitlam Institute’s online forum on the medical school that a student from the university made the following contribution:Indeed, it not only makes good strategic sense to establish a medical school in Western Sydney ... For why should people residing in greater Western Sydney have to travel up to one hour and half to attend a medical school, when the best training ground is in their own back yard?I think that is a reasonable quote. It is important to realise that for south-west Sydney to grow we should have resources like those of the medical school being developed. South-west Sydney has much to offer. It is certainly a ground for significant development not only in industrial production; it is also an area where we are producing many fine students who will be there to service the higher technical industries as they develop.I did mention earlier that, having had the opportunity to meet with and discuss matters with Dr McDonald, I understand the supportive role that does fall to the medical profession in developing further professionals—in his case paediatricians—to be supplied within that area. We do have very committed medical practitioners residing within the region, and I think their contribution certainly needs to be acknowledged in this debate as well. This is not just a matter of making a contribution of $7 million and establishing the medical school; this is the combination of a lot of hard work by many people—including people in this House, which I will freely acknowledge—who are committed to improving the lot of Western Sydney and to the development of educational facilities and clearly focused on what is necessary if they are to advance and improve the productiveness of greater Western Sydney, which obviously encompasses a number of electorates, including that of the member for Macarthur and my own.I am proud to be here to support the efforts to have this medical school established. I look forward to seeing, by the year 2012, doctors being produced by this facility. I would very much hope that the statistics and reports that I quoted earlier do come to fruition. I hope that we manage to attract and retain within south-west Sydney many of the practitioners that would otherwise be encouraged to go elsewhere—places other than Liverpool, Campbelltown and their surrounds.I indicate that, apart from the facilities of the university, there will be a significant integration of training facilities at hospitals such as Campbelltown Hospital and the Liverpool Hospital—and I understand that there will possibly be discussions with Camden Hospital—which will have a significant effect in the placing of students during their practical training. Also, those hospitals will significantly contribute to the educational development of students who attend the medical school on the Campbelltown campus.Those facilities are already staffed by people who are not only qualified but very dedicated professionals. From my discussions with those people, I understand their level of support for this facility. Their personal support is unquestionable. They will certainly do everything that they can possibly do to facilitate the building of strong links so there will be a teaching hospital capability closely linked through curriculum and medical facilities with the school as it is developed at the Campbelltown campus.As I indicated, notwithstanding the concerns I have expressed, I support the development of this institution. I look forward to its opening. Moreover, I look forward to the Campbelltown campus being expanded to include the medical school and to seeing local students given the opportunity to participate and aspire to such a wonderful thing as being a doctor servicing people throughout my local area. I look forward to the prospect of having those students retained as doctors servicing our community.

Speaker: N/A

name: Farmer, Patrick, MP
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Science and Training
content: —In summing up debate on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005 I would like to thank the members of this House who have spoken on the bill for their interest in the issues. However, I wish to correct a few comments made by the member for Jagajaga at the start of the debate and the many errors contained in them.The member for Jagajaga spoke at some length about the financial health of the university sector. I am happy to inject some facts into the picture of doom that she represented here in this place. In 2003, the following results were reported. Sector revenue was $11.9 billion, an increase of around $650 million from 2002. Total net assets were $22.8 billion. Cash investments were $5.6 billion. Over the past five years, net investments and capital assets have totalled $5.2 billion. The financial health of the university sector is strong indeed.The member for Jagajaga also spoke about the purported massive increase in the number of full fee paying students in Australian universities. Again, the facts show exactly the opposite. Last year, there were only 16,299 full fee paying domestic undergraduate students in public universities, of whom 6,086 were undertaking summer and winter courses outside their regular semester study. This number was around three per cent of all domestic undergraduate students in public universities—hardly a massive increase in domestic full fee paying students.The member for Jagajaga made much of the reported high fees for some courses, including a combined medical and law degree at Monash University, reported to cost $256,000. In fact, the university has advised that the combined degree is not currently offered on a fee paying basis, and no decision has been taken to offer it on this basis in 2006. This is clearly scaremongering.The member for Jagajaga claimed that the OECD figures show that the government has taken Australia backward in educational participation and attainment. In fact, educational attainment levels have been increasing steadily. In 1998, some 25.4 per cent of Australians aged between 25 and 64 had tertiary qualifications, according to the OECD. In 2002, this figure was 31 per cent. Australia still has the highest school expectancy, or years in study, at 21.1 years, according to the OECD.Finally, the member for Jagajaga raised the issue of the higher education triennium report—a report put out by the Department of Education, Science and Training each year on the state of higher education in this country. I am happy to say that that report will be available in September. I look forward to the member for Jagajaga having the chance to digest some of the facts in this sector and making a more accurate and informed contribution on higher education at her next opportunity to speak.I would now like to reiterate a few points about the bill before the House. The bill is a further illustration of how the Australian education sector will benefit from the record $7.8 billion investment that the Australian government has made in this sector in the 2005-06 budget. As members will be aware, the policies of this government have resulted in record numbers of students accessing university. The Australian government is making available more Commonwealth funded places than ever before, with 409,393 places this year, an increase of more than 12,000 places over last year. The Australian government is also addressing student demand by funding over 39,000 new student places over five years between 2004 and 2009. These places will enable an estimated additional 50,000 students to study full time or part time at university.The measures in this bill will further strengthen the facilities and the infrastructure available to our universities. As a federal spokesperson for Western Sydney, I and my Western Sydney colleagues are proud to be members of the Howard government, a government that delivers on its commitments to improve the educational options and opportunities for all people in Western Sydney and beyond.This bill will provide the University of Western Sydney with $25 million for new capital infrastructure funding to boost teaching, research and facilities for students over the next three years. As members will recall, in the 2004-05 budget the government pledged $18 million towards the establishment of the university’s new medical school in order to encourage school students in the outer suburbs of Sydney to study medicine and to contribute to their own community. If people study medicine in their local area, there is a good chance they will practise medicine in their local area.This bill provides a further $7 million to the university’s medical school for 2006, making a total government contribution towards the medical school of $25 million. The new medical school will serve the well-documented medical needs of the Western Sydney community and will provide opportunities for students from Western Sydney to study medicine in their own local area.The Western Sydney community will further benefit through the provision in this bill of $7 million for the university’s construction of a new library at its Penrith campus. The new funding for this critical facility will provide library services for UWS staff and students but, just as importantly, also benefit the wider Penrith community, like many other universities around Australia do.This bill also assists students at the University of Western Sydney by providing an additional $9 million towards the establishment of a new teaching building at the University of Western Sydney’s Parramatta campus. Furthermore, this bill provides an additional $2 million to the University of Western Sydney’s Hawkesbury campus to upgrade its research and training facilities. As members would be aware, the university has a long history of providing high-quality agricultural education at Hawkesbury. The funding provided through this bill will further enhance the delivery of educational courses that are of direct benefit to the Australian agricultural sector.These initiatives reflect the Australian government’s ongoing commitment to building better community facilities and providing improved education and opportunities for the people of Western Sydney. The University of Western Sydney puts the people of Western Sydney at the heart of its mission. The university has set itself an aim that over the next 10 years its teaching facilities and practices, research activities, student experiences and community engagement will rank among the best in Australia. The people of Western Sydney deserve no less.In addition to the $25 million of new support to the University of Western Sydney contained in this bill, the Australian government is providing $25.9 million to strengthen the educational and research opportunities in North Queensland. Members would recall that earlier this year the government provided $12 million over two years towards the new veterinary science and agricultural school at James Cook University’s Townsville campus. In recognition of the importance of the study of tropical sciences the government is providing $26 million to James Cook University to fund teaching and research in veterinary science and tropical agriculture.This bill will fund courses in veterinary science and tropical agriculture at James Cook University. It will establish a new undergraduate degree program and provide 50 new places for the courses, including studies in the prevention and early detection of diseases in livestock. The bill also provides an additional 50 places for new undergraduate degree programs in tropical agriculture, giving graduates expertise in tropical plants and exposure to research in vital agricultural areas, such as sugarcane production. These 100 new places in veterinary science and tropical agriculture will commence next year, and by 2009 future undergraduate numbers will rise to 274 places at a cost of $13.9 million.As we have seen elsewhere, new diseases can have devastating consequences across nations, affecting both their rural and urban communities. We must take steps to place Australia at the forefront of the cutting edge research to avert such disasters here. These new undergraduate degrees will provide Australia with expert understanding in the fields of tropical animal diseases and tropical agriculture, which is vital to Australia’s national prosperity.Breakthroughs in the production and the knowledge of plants that thrive in a tropical climate can boost crop production and improve the livelihoods of many Australians, particularly those in the regional and rural communities. It is essential that Australians continue to develop expertise in these fields. The establishment of the new veterinary science and tropical agriculture schools and undergraduate courses will help position James Cook University as a global leader in teaching and research in these fields, further enhancing Australia’s international reputation.The funding provided to James Cook University through this bill reflects the Australian government’s recognition of the unique contribution that regional higher education institutions like James Cook University make to their local communities, for students from rural and regional areas and to our national prosperity.This bill will also amend the maximum funding amounts under the Higher Education Support Act 2003 and the maximum amounts for transition funding under the Higher Education Funding Act 1998 to reflect indexation increases.This bill will enhance both the quality of our higher education systems and the choices available to our students. It also reflects the Australian government’s strong commitment to ensuring that our universities continue to play a vital role in Australia’s economic, cultural and social development. I urge all members of this House to support this bill.Question agreed to.Bill read a second time.Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
content: —It is another day and we have another bill showing yet again the government’s ideological approach to industrial relations. The government has a blinkered view and a divisive approach. There is a preparedness on the part of the government to bend over backwards to meet the extreme views of its constituency. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 again demonstrates that, despite its rhetoric, it is not a government that is governing for all Australians.I have been involved for more than 35 years in aspects of industrial relations in this country. I have had many negotiations, discussions and understandings with people about the best way to get the best results. I have always found that most people are reasonable and are willing to see the other person’s point of view. It has taught me that it is much better to take the cooperative and consultative approach, but that has never been a lesson that this government has understood or practised. It prefers to hammer an ideology and it prefers division and disagreement rather than discussion and agreement.It is very interesting that this government, having been re-elected, refuses to stand by its promise that no worker would be disadvantaged under its brave new world of workplace regulation. Of course they will be disadvantaged. I spoke last week about legislation that would see that disadvantage occasioned. This bill also makes workers worse off. Worst of all, it also seeks to overturn a decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—a decision of the independent umpire. Now that this government has the numbers in both houses, it will legislate away what a tribunal has determined on the merits of the case presented to it.Quite frankly, it is un-Australian not to accept the umpire’s decision. There were a few Australians who were not too happy with the Damien Martyn dismissal last night, but the Australian cricket team with all the tensions involved accepted the decision and went on to get a remarkable draw in the circumstances. It is un-Australian not to accept the umpire’s decision, but that is what this bill does: it overturns the umpire’s decision—a decision which gave employees of small businesses fair redundancy provisions and which was arrived at when parties had had the opportunity to put their case.The commission said that redundancy pay is to compensate employees for the loss of entitlements and credits and for hardship when they are made redundant. The commission’s decision was consistent with moves at the state level to provide for redundancy pay for employees of all businesses. That is what the commission and the states have determined and that is what is fair, but not in the eyes of this government. This bill seeks to overturn that decision. The minister says that it is a flawed decision. We know that the government went to the last election promising the following:A re-elected Coalition will continue to pursue changes to take the unfair dismissal laws burden off the back of small business and protect small business from redundancy payments.In other words, that means that they are going to make it easier to sack people and strip away their protection. That is what it means. They were prepared to assert that in the context of a decision arrived at in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the AIRC.The government talks about the need to protect. I accept that it is important to protect the interests of small business, but it is also important to protect the interests of the people who work for them. It is important to protect people like 15-year-old Deanna Renella—who I spoke about in this place last week and will return to later—an employee of a national franchise chain, Bakers Delight. What about the protection of people like her? That is where the government lacks balance and fairness.This bill seeks to remove redundancy pay requirements for small businesses with fewer than 15 employees, cancel the commission’s decision and override any state laws that provide for redundancy pay for small businesses. The minister says that this legislation does not prohibit the employers from agreeing to redundancy provisions and reaching agreement with their employees, but they are prohibiting the commission determining that outcome when the parties cannot reach agreement.This is a fallacious argument on the part of the government. They say that they want to encourage relationships between employers and employees that envisage this, but, when parties cannot reach agreement and the commission determines—that is the commission’s role—on the case and merits put by the employers and employees and comes down in favour of the decision, the government say, ‘No, you cannot have it; we are going to overturn it.’ In other words, they reject the merits of the case and just proceed with their ideological thrust.I pose a question to the parliamentary secretary at the table and to the government: how realistic is it to expect the balance to be in favour of the employee when they front up to an employer? What do you think an employer is going to say when the employee says, ‘By the way, after that set of conditions, I also want two weeks pay for every year of service if I am made redundant’? What do you think the employer is going to say? It is a fatuous argument; it is nonsense.That is why for a century in this country we have had the Industrial Relations Commission, the independent umpire. But this is a government that is now prepared to torch it, to burn it. If anyone doubts my statement about the balance between employer and employee look at what a judge in the Industrial Relations Court of South Australia had to say in the case I referred to earlier. This is what Judge McCusker had to say on the ability, the balance if you like, of an employee to be able to stand up and bargain on the same terms with an experienced employer:In considering this submission I leave aside for the moment the manifest disadvantage of the respective bargaining positions of a 15 year-old Year 10 student negotiating her terms with an experienced businessman.Of course, he is right. Here is the government talking principle and protection but allowing the types of draconian industrial relations laws and practices that it is overseeing to tip the balance. I heard the Prime Minister last night in an address to the Australian Industry Group and here today in the parliament saying that it is not the intention to tilt the playing field in favour of the employer. If it is not the intention it is certainly what is happening. I believe, quite frankly, that it is the intention because you cannot believe a word the Prime Minister says on this, particularly when he has ditched his no disadvantage test.We on this side of the House accept that small businesses do need some protections. They do need, in the case of the unfair dismissal situation, an ability to deal with the problems of redundancies where there have been litigious and vexatious employees, where demands have been made on them for hush money, where they have been pursued and encouraged by ambulance chasers, where they have been encouraged to pay go-away money and where small businesses that cannot afford the time or the money to defend themselves in court have been forced to pay. They do need protection from those sorts of circumstances.Every time this government, on whatever number of occasions, brought their unfair dismissal legislation into this parliament Labor proposed amendments to give that protection to small businesses, to look after their interests. On every one of those occasions the government were not interested in accommodating or embracing those amendments. They just want the blanket ability to make it easier to sack employees—to improve employment prospects by making it easier to sack people. I have never heard anything more ridiculous in my whole life, and I have had to deal in practical terms with a lot of these issues and a lot of these disputes. The government of the day has to set the framework in which the parties can negotiate and if they cannot resolve it they can have access to an independent umpire. That is the only sensible way these issues can go. If there are people exploiting the system by all means make amendments in the way we have suggested.In relation to the unfair dismissal proposals, we even proposed alternatives that exempted small businesses. Now the government, not content to make exemptions in the case of small businesses, wants to classify and make those exemptions in the case of companies employing fewer than 100 people. Of course, the Treasurer of the country wants to go even further and extend the ability to sack people to any company in the country.This legislation does not address the issue that we have talked about. Labor have proposed sensible amendments previously; the government should look at them again and come back and present a more balanced approach than the one we are experiencing today. Our proposed amendments address the real issues faced by small businesses whilst providing protection and assistance to employees—protection for both sides. We are not stripping protection away from one side and tilting the playing field in favour of the other. Our proposals note that the commission does not believe that in general small businesses do not have the capacity to pay severance pay but it does recognise the fact that some small businesses may not be able to pay.What also concerns me about this legislation is that it may also affect workers’ other legitimate entitlements. The General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS, meets certain employee entitlements in the event that an employer is unable to pay them due to insolvency. GEERS is not legislated, but the government accepted at the time that the community standard of eight weeks pay for redundancy entitlements was the norm. Presumably, it now no longer accepts that community standard. GEERS requires a legal obligation before it pays. This bill may remove that provision. So I would be interested to know, when the government responds on this bill, whether it has the effect on GEERS that I have outlined.Labor have proposed a better alternative in this field too—a trust fund to protect the entitlements of all employees, not just those who happen to work for the company that the Prime Minister’s brother was chairman of. The only time the full entitlements of employees have ever been protected in this country was when Stan Howard’s company got into trouble. We propose the introduction of a trust fund that would have exempted from contributions all small businesses. Here we would have had a win-win outcome—protection for employees and protection for small business because they would not have had to pay. The government again ignored that constructive suggestion because it prefers blind ideology to real solutions.We have now entered an Orwellian world where, as in Animal Farm, four legs good, two legs bad. For this government everything is either black or white: business is good; employees are bad. Do not listen to their rhetoric, look at their track record: AWAs are good; collective agreements are bad. We are prepared to discuss these issues, to look to solutions to reach agreement, but that can only happen if the other side is prepared to do so too.I want to return to the Baker’s Delight case because it is instructive in terms of AWAs and the way in which this bill seeks to strip away protections for certain employees. I raised this matter in the House last week and the Leader of the Opposition questioned the Prime Minister in relation to it. In response, the Prime Minister said that the 15-year-old worker concerned was not covered by a valid AWA. This is correct. He said that the 15-year-old worker was a casual worker and had been underpaid according to the relevant South Australian award. That is also true.That is true, but it is not the point at issue here. Her AWA was only invalid due to a technicality because it had not been filed—it had not been properly witnessed and lodged. If it had been witnessed and lodged properly, she would have been able to have been paid at the lower rate. The court was only able to order restitution in her case for the underpayment of the award rate, the $1,500 payment, because the AWA had not been properly filed. I make that point because the Prime Minister promised that there would be no-one worse off as a result of going on to an AWA. This is the famous no disadvantage test.Clearly, this girl could have been disadvantaged as a result of going on to an AWA. She not only could have been underpaid but also could have lost her sick leave, her annual leave and her annual leave loading—so much for the Prime Minister’s guarantee of no disadvantage. She would have been paid less and she would not have been entitled to those entitlements that I just mentioned because they would have been included in her pay rate—a pay rate 25 per cent lower than the award rate.We even had the situation in which the employer, Yurong Holdings, attempted to argue that the worker was allowed to take home a loaf of bread and that that should be taken into account. I have heard the argument ‘Let them eat cake,’ but now, under the brave new world of industrial relations that the Prime Minister talks about, we are paying people with loaves of bread. This is an outrage, yet it is the system that this government is encouraging.It gets worse, because the employer tried to blacken the worker’s reputation—a 15-year-old girl—by saying that she ‘is believed to be responsible for a till deficit of $751’. The judge in this case said:This is a very grave allegation. It is pressed on appeal. Yet not one piece of probative evidence beyond assertion was identified or suggested to back it up.This is the brave new world of AWAs. This is the evenness, the protection and the no disadvantage that the Prime Minister talks about. No wonder he is not prepared to give a no disadvantage test now, because it is worth nothing in the current climate, and he is going to strip it away.I make this point because it is terribly important: the girl in that case was able to get restitution because the court ordered that she be paid. Why? Because the technical failure to lodge the AWA meant she was not covered by an AWA and had to be covered by the industrial law of South Australia. But what about the other 50 workers employed by the same company under precisely the same terms where the AWA was validly lodged? These people must be underpaid too by any reasonable objective test, yet they cannot get restitution. That is the problem. Here we have a government that says, ‘Unions cannot have collective pattern bargaining,’ but is prepared to condone pattern bargaining in terms of AWAs that strip away entitlements and underpay people. The no disadvantage test cited by this government is worthless. This legislation is stripping away collective rights and undermining entitlements. It is bad legislation and it should be opposed (Time expired).

Speaker: N/A

name: Cadman, Alan, MP
content: —The previous speaker, the member for Hotham, raised one issue of a girl working for McDonald’s in South Australia as being the total basis of Labor’s opposition to this proposal. Let me go through some of the cases that have been described by the former opposition spokesman for small business, the member for Watson, as ‘go-away money’. Let me describe some of the instances of go-away money that have been the cause of the government’s concern and small business’s concern about this issue.Sharan Burrow, in a presentation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Human Services inquiry into balancing work and family claimed that research shows that 93 per cent of employees in the private sector on individual contracts have no additional family rights. Let us have a look at that research and get some accuracy because, as always, the Australian Labor Party’s comments have to be read in detail and then referred to the original statements.The ACTU omits the following information, which has come from the research that Sharan Burrow quoted from. AWA employees are more satisfied than collective employees that they are rewarded for their effort—44 per cent to 29 per cent. Nearly twice as many AWA recipients compared with employees on collective agreements are happy with their reward. This is the research that Sharan Burrow would not quote. Out of a range of figures indicating how successful AWAs have been for most employees, she chose to quote to a parliamentary committee one figure on family issues, neglecting to mention the others. I will go through them. AWA employees are more satisfied with the change in their pay and conditions—38 per cent to 29 per cent; that is a 50 per cent advantage for people on AWAs compared with those on collective agreements. AWA employees felt they had more influence over decisions affecting them in the workplace—69 per cent to 65 per cent. AWA employees were more likely to say that stress in the workplace had reduced over the last two years—19 per cent to 14 per cent; while collective employees are more likely to say stress has increased—49 per cent to 37 per cent. AWA employees are more likely to say that management does its best to get along with staff—64 per cent to 44 per cent. AWA employees are more likely to feel that management gives them a say in how they do their job—58 per cent to 35 per cent. Giving only an insignificant part of the story forms the basis of the way the Australian Labor Party is operating during this debate, and that is pretty typical.The minister today indicated how workers in small businesses would continue to be protected against inappropriate conduct by their employers. For example, it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss or victimise an employee for refusing to agree to a new workplace agreement. That is not being run by the Australian union movement or the Australian Labor Party. They say that people will be penalised by being sacked if they do not agree to a new workplace agreement. That is not true. It is a blatant lie being told by the union movement and the ALP on this issue. The Office of the Employment Advocate will continue to provide a strong inspection service. In 2003-04, the Office of Workplace Services concluded over 4,700 investigations into breaches of federal industrial law. But what did the leader of the ACTU say in these circumstances? She said, ‘I need a dad or a mum of someone who has been seriously injured or killed; that would be fantastic to run’—I suppose, as part of their publicity campaign. What a way to look at these issues, just to search for the tragic loss of an individual to publicise the union part of this campaign.Let us look at some of the specifics. Why does small business feel so reluctant to employ when there is the prospect of unfair dismissals? Sharan Burrow says, ‘It’s only a matter of process; fix up the process and everything will be okay.’ The previous speaker for the opposition tended to say the same thing—‘We are now ready to talk; we are now ready to listen to the government.’ For years those opposite have rejected the government’s approach to consider, for small business, a modification. Peter Reith and subsequent ministers, Tony Abbott and now Kevin Andrews, have tried many times to talk logically to the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party in every instance in the Senate rejected our approaches about making it fairer for small business. Even your shadow spokesman, Tony Burke, said that this was go-away money that was being demanded. He said, ‘There is go-away money being demanded’—and there is. Let me give you a few examples.
