name: Cadman, Alan, MP
content: —The member at the table should be very interested to hear of an employee of a manufacturer who was dismissed for physically assaulting a coworker. The New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission reinstated the employee, finding that there had been an unfair dismissal. An employee from another factory was dismissed for sleeping on the job and falsifying the attendance records. But, in an extraordinary decision, the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission determined that the dismissal was unfair. He had been sleeping on the job and falsifying the records and was then reinstated. This is happening time and again. Small business knows of these instances, so why would they be prepared to employ extra people? They know that, if the process goes to court, there is a cost of between $5,000 and $20,000. So what do they do? They pay go-away money to the employee involved.In another instance an employee removed over $15,000 from a safe, lent it to an off-duty colleague and then falsified the reconciliation documents relating to the safe. The money was gambled away and the employee was sacked. He was subsequently reinstated by the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission to a supervisory position where he still would be responsible for large amounts of cash, notwithstanding his complete breach of protocol and the employer’s trust. Under the unfair dismissal provisions of the legislation that Laurie Brereton brought into this place, which was approved by this parliament, that is the stupid situation we have with small business and the reinstatement of people. This government has been consistently trying to get rid of the problems the Brereton legislation has created.Not all of these instances make the front page of newspapers, but the Daily Telegraph on Monday, 4 July told the story of the New South Wales Department of Education and Training being incapable of doing anything and being unprepared to sack a teacher who had been convicted of possessing 600 images of child pornography. This teacher in the New South Wales system was convicted of possessing 600 pages of pornography and the department was not prepared to sack this person because it feared being hit with another unfair dismissal case. Why did the New South Wales Department of Education and Training feel this way? Because the department had recently had to reinstate and pay out $28,000 to a teacher it had sacked for having an affair with a pupil, the department was not prepared to move when it found another teacher with 600 pages of child pornography. That is how this process is working.The Australian subsidiary of an offshore manufacturer had a major problem with an aggressive employee who engaged in verbal abuse and other intimidatory behaviour against other employees and management. A serious concern for this employer was the length of time that due process took to dismiss the employee under the present New South Wales legislation. Legal costs of some $40,000 were incurred, but the greatest concerns were the safety, morale and OH&S problems that persisted until the employee could be removed from the premises. So there were long, protracted processes, with the troubled person still on the job and the employer being unable to remove the individual. Therefore, the dangerous situation continued and legal costs amounted to $40,000 to get rid of and solve the problem.A tourist operator received complaints from the passengers of a particular bus driver. The passengers complained that the driver was rude and had taken the passengers on an alcohol-induced wild ride. The bus operator gave the bus driver a chance to redeem himself only to find that another group of passengers were also taken on a wild ride. The sacked driver took the operator to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission. The commission found the employer was justified in sacking the driver but then found that the operator had to pay his own costs of $12,000. The operator is no longer in business. This is the thing that employers fear. This is the thing that worries them. I have them in my electorate, and they come to see me.A pub owner employed a young woman who said that she wanted to work part time, four days a week. Within two weeks she had told him that she wanted to work only two days a week and, two weeks later, said that she was pregnant and wanted to work only one day. The pub owner said, ‘I’m sorry. I really wanted somebody for four days; that was what you were employed to do. I am going to have to let you go and get somebody who can work for four days.’ He let her go, and there was an unfair dismissal claim of $10,000. That bloke nearly lost the pub and nearly lost the capacity to continue his business. He did not have a spare $10,000 in cash to resolve this matter. He came to see me and I tried to resolve the matter. The court had decided that he had to pay the money and, even though the terms and conditions of employment were clearly stated and understood by the employee, they were abused by the employee and this small business man found himself up for the amount of $10,000. It is completely unfair.But the protection needs to remain for employees, and the protection will remain for employees, as the minister said today. It will be unlawful for people to be dismissed if they refuse to sign an AWA. That will not change. It will continue to be unlawful for people to force someone else into an AWA that they do not want or to dismiss somebody for a temporary absence from work due to illness or disability. All that will continue; it will not change. But the crazy idea that unfair dismissal meant that you could dream up something, that you could have a grievance against an employer, that you could be vexatious in your claims or that you could be angry because you had lost your job and wanted to get back at your employer is going to be removed, because it is stalling employment opportunities for others. Those who make angry or vexatious claims, those who can see an easy way of claiming $5,000 to $10,000 from a former employer, are going to have to find a different way of earning their money because this is going to stop. They will no longer be able to get at the employer for easy cash. They are going to have to find different ways of getting their money, and it is only fair that they should make way for those following behind them who want to work.Another story is that of a manufacturing company repeatedly warning an employee about inappropriate conduct and language. A final warning was given to the employee when he threw a tool at another employee. The employee was finally sacked when he again verbally abused another employee. So this guy was a menace to his own workmates and to himself, throwing tools at them and abusing them. The employee brought an unfair dismissal claim, and the commission found that the employer acted fairly towards the employee in relation to procedural issues. Therefore, the proper warnings were given and the appropriate processes were gone through in relation to this employee, who had been abusive to his workmates and to those around him in throwing tools at them. The commission found that the process the employer had gone through of warning this guy, saying that his behaviour was unacceptable and then finally sacking him was satisfactory and that the employer had followed all the procedural processes. But the commission then determined that the abusive behaviour and remarks to other employees was not a valid reason for summary dismissal. The commission determined that the dismissal was unfair and awarded compensation to the applicant, in addition to substantial costs to the employer in the form of management time and legal costs.I have another story. A US professional service organisation decided to close its office in Australia. A manager who was on maternity leave at the time received redundancy pay and all other entitlements. This person was the company’s representative. The professional services organisation decided to close its doors. The manager, who was on maternity leave, quite appropriately received redundancy pay and all the other entitlements. Nonetheless she alleged that the decision was taken in response to her being absent on maternity leave and claimed additional compensation through an unfair dismissal claim. The US based employer, unfamiliar with the principles that operate in this country and with Australian law and concerned that the allegations could affect its reputation, engaged a solicitor. It is normal for an overseas company to want to maintain its good name. In spite of the claim having no merit whatsoever, the employer became concerned that its defence would consume excessive resources and settled with a payout. That is what it is about: the capacity to bluff somebody into paying you when there is no reason to receive payment—and that has to stop. This needs to stop in Australia. It is a cancer that eats away at the relationships between people, particularly people in small businesses—the very businesses whose livelihoods and success depend on trust between a small number of people. That is what is eating at the core of small business employment in Australia today.The Australian Labor Party has had many opportunities to agree with changes. If it was the process that was the problem, as Sharan Burrows is now saying, we could have agreed to a process and we could have settled it in the Senate. But the Australian Labor Party decided, ‘No, we’ll tough it out’. The game has changed and it is going to go through and be restored to where it should be. It is not going to be unfair to employees, because every employee in Australia is going to have these basic protections. Those in large businesses will have a few additional ones, but those in small businesses will have all the basic protections of their salaries, holidays, sick leave and unfair dismissal if there is a dismissal for not signing an AWA or for temporary absence or illness—it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss a worker because of absence at work due to family responsibilities. All of that will continue. It will continue to be unlawful to dismiss an employee for filing a complaint or participating in proceedings against an employer involved in alleged violation of laws and regulations. None of these things are going to change. They are all going to be there. The protections for employees in small businesses remain. What will go is the capacity to dream up some trumped up charge against a former employer and threaten them with court—threaten them into having to take time off and leave their place of business and not be able to carry out their duties because there is only a small number of people in the enterprise, and threaten them with financial damage because of the need to be off the job defending a trumped up case in a court.That is going to change because those former employees are going to have to find genuine cause from now on as to why the employer has dealt badly with them. I have read out probably a dozen cases and one from my electorate. I know that there are many more out there like this, and all the Australian Labor Party can come up with is a case that is under the current law and not even an unfair dismissal case, claiming that as the reason why these changes should be opposed. I have never heard such a weak argument. I have never seen Simon Crean on such thin ice. I have never seen the leaders of the Australia Labor Party grasping at straws like this to make a case. I have never seen the ACTU so desperate that they want to see a person dead on the job or maimed or seriously injured in order to support their case. I think it is disgusting that the Australian Labor Party can so abuse workers—its so-called supporters; half its membership—in this way. I know Australia is going to change for the better when this change comes into place. (Time expired)

Speaker: N/A

name: O’Connor, Brendan, MP
content: —I am not entirely surprised that the member for Mitchell has problems understanding what we are saying, because he is clearly speaking to the wrong bill. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 does not deal with unlawful termination; this bill concerns whether or not small businesses should have exemption for redundancy payments. It is an important matter for us to debate and the member for Mitchell was clearly speaking to the wrong bill. He was obviously focusing his energies on unlawful termination when what he should have been doing was considering the bill before us and, indeed, the amendments moved by the member for Perth.This bill reminds me of the extent to which the government is willing to go to override any other party who would like to determine a particular matter—in this particular case, of course, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It was charged with the responsibility of listening to parties, pursuant to the Workplace Relations Act 1996, making applications on whether or not there should be changes to the TCR provisions to allow the possibility for employees to be in receipt of redundancy payment if they were made redundant and happen to be unlucky enough to work in a small workplace—for an employer with fewer than 15 employees.That is the nub of this matter. Last year the full bench of the Industrial Relations Commission determined that, yes, there should be some capacity for Australian workers who work for a company with fewer than 15 employees to be in receipt of some payment if indeed they were unfortunately retrenched. There were a number of reasons why the commission determined that way. I can assure all members in this place of this: the ACTU made its applications, the major employer bodies made their applications and the commission rejected parts of all submissions made and determined what they believed to be a balanced and reasonable decision. In the end they sought to amend the TCR provisions so as to include the capacity for employees in those smaller workplaces to be in receipt of redundancy. They acknowledged that there would be circumstances in which small businesses may not be able to pay, and so they went to the matter of incapacity to pay. But they also recognised the changing nature of our economy and the fact that a much greater proportion of employees are now working for smaller employers since the 1984 TCR decision was made. Twenty years on, the commission, headed by Justice Giudice—a government appointee, and some would argue a wise president, but certainly someone who has standing in society—who indeed presided over this matter, determined that there had to be some way in which employees were not unreasonably discriminated against by their fate of working for an employer with fewer than 15 employees. So the decision determined to allow for a maximum of eight weeks payment if someone were so tragically made redundant.I for one do not agree with the contention that we on this side do not accept that it is a difficulty for small businesses. In fact, today the government had an opportunity to allow small businesses to be represented by whom they wished and withdraw the provisions of the proposed Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. At the moment, if enacted, that legislation would proscribe the rights of small businesses to have employee organisations represent them. If you want to talk about the rights of small businesses, here was an opportunity today for the government. In the gallery we had many small business people—people who are on occasion in a great deal of debt, purchasing their own rig and placing themselves in a position where they must receive an income just to keep up with the payments of the debt for that rig. They came here today to ask the government to reconsider the way in which it seeks to limit their rights—not unions’ rights; the rights of small business people—to be represented by trade unions if they so wish. Indeed, they have a right to choose anyone else.It is quite extraordinary that the government manages to distinguish organisations like the Australian cricket association or other employee bodies from employee organisations registered under the Workplace Relations Act. This again highlights the fact that it is even willing to hurt small businesses if it can in some way adversely affect trade unions. So we do not really need a lecture from the member for Mitchell or any other member on the other side in relation to the concerns that small businesses have.I return to this bill and say: we would hope that small businesses are not affected. We would hate to see the case whereby a company is so commercially affected or in some way injured that it cannot continue to employ as many employees in its work force. But of course we need to have some balance in the argument.It is instructive that the ACCI, the AiG and other peak employer bodies quite rightly represented their views, the views of their members—that is, the many employers in this country—and submitted their position to the commission, the statutory authority, the independent umpire that has been around for over a century. Indeed, the ACTU on behalf of registered organisations of employees did likewise. As a result of that, the independent umpire rejected parts and accepted parts of submissions made by all parties and came up with what would seem to be a reasoned position. It was not an extreme position, as it has been purported to be—that is currently being put forward by the government in relation to industrial relations generally—but a position that balanced the rights, concerns and entitlements of employees and the obligations of employers in that regard. It was also a commercially sound decision, to ensure that there was not too great an impost upon small businesses.Further to that—and I certainly have not heard this mentioned today in the debate—when the employers, along with the Commonwealth and other bodies, made subsequent submissions before the full bench, the full bench amended its decision of 26 March 2004 on 8 June in that same year. It said that recognition of the years that would have to be calculated to determine a redundancy payment would not commence until this year. In other words, there would be no contingent liability held by any small business on the basis of the decision and the amendments that were made by the commission in June last year. So, again, that was a very sound, reasoned and careful decision.I ask the members opposite to consider reading at least parts of the 103-page decision, because I think it allows members opposite—who seem to have an extraordinary ignorance about industrial matters, in some respects anyway—to realise how much effort goes into not only the submissions by the parties on behalf of employees and employers in this country but the efforts by the commissioners to make a decision that is fair and reasonable to all parties. We have to juxtapose that behaviour—of process, of listening to arguments, of finding a decent and reasonable determination—with the extremes of this government in relation to its attacks on working people.We have seen its willingness to deny small businesses the right to be represented in certain matters by trade unions but by no other. The government mantra ‘right to choose’, if genuine, would allow anybody to be an agent for a particular party if that party wished them to be so. But of course the blind hatred the government has towards unions unfortunately blurs propriety. It blurs the right and wrong in this matter. Equally, there is a failure of the government to see that there has to be some balance between protecting small businesses on the one hand and protecting small business employees on the other in relation to a prospective redundancy. It is not getting that balance right but is instead overriding the Industrial Relations Commission and its decision. If you look at the evidence and the submissions made by the parties, you will find that the decision really comes down the middle of the two respective submissions.I go to the statement that has been made by the full bench. The statement does provide for an increase. In the broader sense, beyond the application for small businesses, it provides for greater increases in redundancy payments for four years up to 10 years. It does not change at all the current entitlements for less than one year up to four years. Remember that that relates to more than 50 per cent of the work force these days, so clearly it is a very important part of the decision. I do not necessarily agree with it, but the commission felt that an increase would be an impost and chose not to support that. Whilst the commission accepts that small businesses should indeed pay a redundancy if they are able to, it suggests that it should be a maximum of only eight weeks. So there is still consideration of the position of the small business.I will not compare the government’s position with the opposition’s position and I will not compare the government with previous Labor governments; I will compare this government with previous conservative governments. I have to say that by any comparison, particularly in this area, this government is very antiworker. You would not see Menzies, Fraser, Harold Holt or other conservative governments legislate on every occasion possible to prevail over a decision made by a statutory authority that is charged with a responsibility to hear submissions, undertake a due process and proper consideration of matters and determine a particular outcome. You would not see such injudicious intrusion by those governments into these matters. But you do see it, constantly, with this government. It is a major problem. I know members opposite are concerned. Every time I raise my own fears that this government has it in for working people—

name: O’Connor, Brendan, MP
content: —I understand the member for Flinders wants to open his mouth. Maybe he should enter the debate, rather than challenge me from the table. The member for Flinders knows, and his predecessor certainly knew, how to stick it to workers. Certainly his predecessor knew all about balaclavas and attack dogs; I can assure you of that. The current member for Flinders at least seems to be a more temperate soul in relation to these matters, but I may be wrong, given that he wants to interject while I am trying to contribute to the debate properly.It is very unusual for a government to continually legislate to prevail over decisions made by the Industrial Relations Commission. So I hope the government reconsiders its position. The government is in a very powerful position; I understand that. The government is in a very powerful position in both houses, and I believe that when you have so much power you should use it wisely. You have a responsibility to use it wisely.The amendment moved by the member for Perth, the shadow minister responsible for this area, really says: why not reconsider the decision made by the commission to determine the matter, because it is a balanced decision? The amendment moved by the member for Perth asks that the House note:(1) ... that the nation’s independent umpire in industrial relations matters, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), has examined and heard submissions concerning the impact of redundancy payments on small business;(2) ... that the AIRC has found that the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small business across the board does not have the capacity to pay—and, importantly, that the House recognise—(3) ... the circumstances of those individual small business which are incapable of making redundancy payments.That is an even-tempered, well-balanced proposition that the government would accept if it were not so extreme in its outlook with relation to working people. That is the difficulty that this side of the House has with this matter. We understand that there will be differences of opinion; however, the government should consider whether it is motivated by the wrong reasons—motivated not to create good public policy but to hurt groups that do not agree with the government of the day. We see that now with the government’s attacks on students and registered employee organisations. A wise government, in light of its power, would reconsider its approach and try to reflect some balance.To date there has been a grave failure of the government to do that. I think the government is making a mistake in selling Telstra, and it is making a mistake in not allowing student organisations to run at campus level in the manner in which they have been. I think the government is making a mistake in preventing small businesses from being represented by unions if they so wish. The government is denying them that right by bringing into the House the Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005, which effectively removes the choice. It is the opposite of what the government preaches about the rights of principals and their agents—it removes the choice.I would like to finish my contribution to this debate by saying that the government has an opportunity to find the right balance between small businesses and their employees and to ensure that the rights and considerations of each other’s position is extended to both. Unfortunately it would seem that, unless there is a change of heart by the government, the workers of this country will get it in the neck again.
debateinfo: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT (SMALL BUSINESS EMPLOYMENT PROTECTION) BILL 2004
Speaker: N/A

name: Laming, Andrew, MP
content: —There is no doubt that the small businesses—all one million of them—are performing well in this country. They are the very engine room of continued growth, and this side of the House will never forget that. They are the backbone of the strong economy that we in this country enjoy. Without doubt, many small businesses are very profitable but we must never confuse that profitability with the ability to afford large redundancy payments. You only have to work in small business to know just how hard that can be. That is precisely why it is completely outmoded to come into this House to talk about preventing retrenchments in business—be they small or micro—by applying severance pay to those who create jobs in this country. Placing an obligation on small business to make those redundancy payments will simply lead to an additional cost impost on the very wrong group if you want a strong economy and more job opportunities. It would be unaffordable for many small businesses, and that is the case that I will make tonight.Clearly employees of small business will not gain anything from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision that we are debating today if they have no job to go to as a result of that decision. The member for Gorton gave a very considered 15 minutes about the removal of choice and about both parties having rights. He also provided something that I hear very rarely: a robust defence of the AIRC, which underlines this country’s flawed process of averaging out the submissions from two completely divergent parties and making decisions based on that. We just flail around in a miasma of ambit claims, with the member for Gorton satisfied that a decision between the two means that everyone is being looked after.We have to be far more considered, and we must ask ourselves two key questions. The first is from a small business perspective. Have you ever run a small business of three, four or five people, where your employees are effectively members of your commercial family, and been faced with making that horrible decision? The decision of redundancy is not necessarily affordable. Are the right parties taking responsibility for a decision to restructure or to make somebody redundant? The second question is from the point of view of the worker. No doubt there is hardship when one loses employment. Who should pay for that restructure or that move? To make the case that the small business should be penalised for doing what it does best is about placing the punishment on the very group that can least afford it. The opposition has to make a case that someone else should pay. (Quorum formed)It is the height of effrontery for the member for Gorton to simply hold up a piece of paper from the AIRC and claim that, because they said that redundancy payments were affordable for small business, they are. Anyone who has run a small business would know that that is far from the truth. The second case that has not been made by the opposition, of course, is: if there is going to be hardship that needs to be met for those who lose their jobs, why is it that small business needs to pay? If welfare for those who lose a job is to be considered in this country then I say that that case has not been made by the opposition.The one lesson that we have learnt from having those on the other side of the House in government is that you can certainly and quite easily regulate to increase costs, but you cannot regulate to save jobs, because only real jobs deliver job security. You need the conditions whereby small business feels confident to create those jobs. We on this side of the House think it is imperative that small business, as a sector, has every opportunity to be supported to put on and employ as many people as possible, and this legislation is a great example of doing just that. It will serve Australia’s small businesses well and it will save them the decision and the cost burden being imposed by the AIRC.Preceding me, what we had from the member for Gorton was 15 minutes of considered reason whereupon he hit the wall and basically collapsed into some antiworker ramble and antigovernment diatribe. For 15 minutes we had some belief that by averaging out the parties at the AIRC we could make great employment and workplace policy in this country. That is patently not the case. If we are trying to seek an optimum balance then we have to find a balance of interests. That is not necessarily an average between the two claims of two parties at the AIRC.There are obviously the equally meritorious considerations of looking after the welfare of workers and making decisions that are best for business. But tonight we are considering those who employ fewer than 15 people. It is not that hard as a microbusiness to find yourself employing 15 people. It is completely time-wasting to be considering one side at the expense of another. That completely hostile, 1890s type approach to industrial relations, as we have heard from a couple of speakers on the other side, where they simply raise examples of vexatious employers, or they give ludicrous examples of being summarily dismissed over the phone for one’s family requirements or looking after children, is completely unrealistic. Redundancy is never taken lightly by reasonable employers, and we need to be looking after the welfare of those who are made redundant. The case that has not been made tonight is that weeks and weeks of pay should be the responsibility of small business when they are employing fewer than 15 people. That is a case that has not been made, and to simply assume it should be because the AIRC said it is so is to misunderstand what it is like to be in small business.The AIRC effectively tried to remove that exemption for businesses of fewer than 15 people. That redundancy scale that was set up in 1984 that applies to larger businesses has been in place since then and ranges between four and eight weeks. It is interesting to remember that it was not so long ago that the ACTU came to the AIRC with another series of ambit claims. It does serve this parliament well to remember what they were: an attempt to double the existing award redundancy payment obligations on employers from eight weeks to—wait for it!—20 weeks; to extend redundancy pay to casual employees; to include penalty rates and overtime payments in redundancy; and to add an additional allowance for employment and financial advice. That was the ambit claim coming from the other side that, in some way over time, led to this decision made early last year.This Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 will do important things. It will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to ensure that the allowability of redundancy pay is limited to those who employ more than 15 people. It will provide that any variations made to the award since March of last year, that are effectively imposing redundancy pay obligations on employers with fewer than 15 employees, will have no effect. It prevents the commission from making redundancy pay orders under section 170FA against an employer who has fewer than 15 workers, and it overrides any territory laws that might impose similar redundancy pay obligations.Of course the evidence from leading economists supports the case I am making tonight. Businesses will feel reluctant to restructure if they are being rendered less efficient and if they are being rendered less capable to adjust to or to reflect changes in the workplace and markets. They will be more prone to closure, less resilient to future crises and, in the end, offer less security to all the other employees in the business. They will be less able to renew, less able to pursue new opportunities in a high-risk environment and obviously less able to grow. Single or partial redundancies, if they are made impossible to do or extremely expensive for small business, eventually simply threaten the entire business. There is an increased capacity to make viable restructuring that saves all other employees.We should also look at the other side of the story; economic and employment conditions are very different to how they were 10 years ago. There are a large range of services that actually make redundancies—while I would never ever want to go through the experience of redundancy—far less harrowing than they were just 10 years ago. We have a near-universal award redundancy scheme in place for employers with more than 15 people; that has been in place for 20 years, but extending it down to the smallest—the microbusinesses, I call them—will do nothing to improve workplace relations. It will not do anything to improve competitiveness. It will not do anything to help efficiency, productivity or, in the end, the jobs, the products and the production that they are responsible for. It will not do anything to help the opportunities for future growth.Expanding these existing standards down to the smallest businesses simply fails them, because the redundancy payments increase currently for length of service and one’s salary, but for the smallest of businesses these payments can sometimes be crippling. I completely reject the assessment of the AIRC that there is the capacity to pay in all microbusiness. The other side of the House is ignoring the fundamental point that employees are gaining just as much as their bosses in a strong contemporary labour market. The Australian redundancy standards, currently funded by employers, compare extremely well internationally, and in many cases are even higher.Career expectations are changing. Individuals today have realistic and well-understood expectations about training, working, retraining and changing places of occupation. How companies now train, retrain and retain their staff means that workers will seek re-employment based upon their experience, their training and their retraining, so it is a far more fluid and flexible work market than ever before.There is already an increasing investment by employers and governments in education and training, and there is a trend towards more transportable skills. Both from an active and a passive labour point of view, the market assistance that is available in the community to assist in the process through redundancy and back into employment is witnessed by some of the shortest periods of unemployment between jobs that we have seen in a generation.My case tonight concerns extending these laws to the smallest of business. Many of these employers are taking home extraordinarily low salaries. Often their businesses are struggling. At a time when additional regulation is expected, this can only cause more trouble and more uncertainty within a small business.The alternative from the other side is this. If the small business is not to pay redundancy payments, precisely who should be paying them? We have not yet had any coherent argument that government should be paying them. That would be the case that would have to be made if, as the member for Gorton said, we could find some middle ground. Effectively there has been no regard to the economic benefits that we have seen in this country that make redundancy a very different proposition from what it was a decade ago.Of course, businesses have a commercial and a legal obligation to run and to act in the best interests of their employees and either the business itself or its owners. In some unavoidable cases, that does lead to redundancy. But why should we penalise the smallest of businesses for what is effectively commercial commonsense, if not commercial law?In conclusion, let me say this. Losing your job can be an absolute kick in the guts. There is no doubt that that is the case for those who face termination of employment. The case that needs to be made tonight concerns whether the burden of redundancy payments should be placed upon small businesses themselves. Redundancy is never completely the fault of one party or the other. There are multiple parties that suffer from redundancy and that are likely to be affected by a decision to restructure, to make a company more effective and efficient or to respond to the demands of the marketplace. That burden should not be rested with the smallest of small business in this community. It rests with individuals; it rests with society more generally, through government, taxation, welfare support, retraining and the labour market opportunities that this government is providing.
debateinfo: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT (SMALL BUSINESS EMPLOYMENT PROTECTION) BILL 2004
Speaker: N/A

name: Bowen, Chris, MP
content: —Once again I find myself following the honourable member for Bowman, and doing so after he has done an admirable job of trying to defend the indefensible. The honourable member for Bowman put together a mishmash of arguments to defend the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004, which takes away not the rights of workers but the rights of ordinary people to be sustained in their moment of greatest need.This is an example of this government’s extreme industrial relations agenda that we see time and time again in this House. It is also an example of this government’s confused and schizophrenic approach to small business. This government thinks that the only way it can help small business is to pit the owners of small businesses against their employees. It thinks that there is always a zero sum game—that the only way the proprietors of small business can benefit is to take something away from the employees of small business. We on this side of the House have a very different approach. We say that small business can be helped and that the employees of small business can be helped at the same time. Our entire small business policy supports that argument.This government finds itself in the situation where it has breached its promises to small business. It has not delivered at all for small business. It is strong on rhetoric but small on delivery. It can only take away from the employees of small business to benefit the owners of small business.The honourable member for Bowman talked about a miasma of ambit claims. He talked about small business being less able to renew. Small businesses will still be able to renew if the Labor Party’s amendments are adopted, but they will be able to renew in such a way that the innocent victims of downturns in the economy and, sometimes, poor management decisions do not have their livelihoods taken away in such a way that they are unable to put food on the table. That is what this government is doing.This bill overturns the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to ensure and entrench the redundancy rights of employees of small businesses. The bill appears to ignore a supplementary decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which essentially agreed with the submissions of the Commonwealth and the employers, particularly the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Industry Group.The commission noted that small businesses may lack the financial reserves to meet redundancy payments arising out of the March decision. Accordingly, the commission varied its March decision and decided that, for the purposes of calculating redundancy payments, small business employers need take into account only employment service rendered after 8 June 2004. This means that the contingent liability of small business is zero until June 2005, irrespective of the employee’s years of service. The commission’s recognition of the potential of some small businesses to have difficulty in paying is sensible, as is the commission’s solution. I was drawn to the commissioners’ decision, and in particular the following excerpt from it:While some small businesses lack financial resilience and have less ability to bear the costs of severance pay than larger businesses, the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small business does not have the capacity to pay severance pay. In the period 1997-98, the most recent period for which data are available, some 70 per cent of small businesses which reduced the number of persons they employed made a profit. For those businesses which are unable to meet their redundancy pay obligations the incapacity to pay provision, as amended by this decision, provides an avenue for relief.Neither the honourable member for Bowman nor any other government member, to my knowledge, has referred to that particular finding of the commission. Those opposite say, ‘No small business will be able to pay this. We are lifting the burden off small business.’ They say the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has not considered this matter properly. They do not recognise the fact that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has done considerable research. It did not toss a coin or say, ‘The employers say this; the unions say this. We’ll go fifty-fifty.’ It was a considered decision which has been ignored by the honourable member for Bowman, by other members opposite and—surprise, surprise—by this government in its extreme approach.The commission’s approach is a sensible one. It approaches the capacity or incapacity of a small business to pay on a case-by-case basis. It is an approach that the opposition endorses. The government has endorsed another approach—an extremist approach. This is the logic of the government’s argument. The government says that, if you work for a company with 16 employees, you should get redundancy pay. However, if you are unfortunate enough to work for a company with 14 employees, you miss out.Let us go back to first principles. The honourable member for Bowman said one thing that I agree with: if you lose your job, it can be a kick in the guts. What is redundancy pay for? It is to help people who lose their jobs through no fault of their own. It has been generally accepted on both sides of politics, indeed throughout the Western world, that redundancy pay is legitimate. But rather than adopting a case-by-case approach, rather than adopting the principle of capacity to pay, the government has taken the approach of simply abolishing the rights of people who work for companies with 15 or fewer employees to redundancy pay. The government has failed over its nine years in office to deal with the matter of employee entitlements generally. I have a private member’s bill before the House on this matter.The government, after the scandal of national textiles and Ansett, introduced the General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS. I would like to address the intersection of this bill and the GEERS. The scheme meets certain employee entitlements in the event that an employer is unable to pay due to insolvency. However, the entitlement to payment under the scheme is generated by evidence of (a) the entitlement and its accrual and (b) a legal obligation to meet the entitlement. This bill potentially removes the right to access the GEERS for employees of certain small businesses. By removing the right to redundancy pay, this bill removes the entitlement to redundancy pay and therefore potentially removes the capacity of some employees to access the GEERS. So this government says it is all about capacity to pay but, with this bill, it removes the rights of employees to access a scheme that is not paid for by small business—

name: Bowen, Chris, MP
content: —The honourable member for Moncrieff will have his opportunity. He caterwauls from the back in his normal right-wing manner. My friend the honourable member for Moncrieff rushes into this House for any opportunity to support the government’s extreme right-wing industrial relations agenda, as is his perfect right. He caterwauls from the back. I challenge the honourable member for Moncrieff to deal with the intersection of the GEERS and this bill. I challenge him to explain to this House why the GEERS will not be affected by this bill. I challenge him to explain this government’s approach to employee entitlements generally. I challenge him to defend the government’s record on employee entitlements, the national textiles disaster, the Ansett imbroglio et cetera.This government’s rhetoric on small business is strong; its record is poor. Is this a priority for small business? As I have said before in the House, I spend as much time as I can talking to small businesses in my electorate. Not one of them has raised the need for exemption from redundancy payments. As I have said before, small business regularly raises with me the need to be freed up from unnecessary paperwork. This is something that the government has made much worse. The government promised to cut small business paperwork by 50 per cent. Instead, it has increased small business paperwork substantially. We have seen the GST and superannuation choice—two massive burdens on small business and their paperwork compliance regime.Some small businesses have also had a significant increase in their paperwork and compliance costs as a result of financial services reform. One small business in the financial services field that I know of in my electorate has gone out of business because of these reforms. If the government’s reality matched its rhetoric, we would see much more action on these fronts and less ideologically driven attacks on the employees of small businesses, which create two or even three classes of citizens.There will be three classes of small business employees in this country if this bill is passed. There is the class where, if you work for a company with fewer than 15 employees, you have the right to be dismissed and you have no right to retrenchment. If you work for a company with between 15 and 100 employees, you could still be dismissed but you will have some rights to retrenchment pay. If you are lucky enough to work for a company with more than 100 employees then you are right on both fronts. This government is so ideologically confused that it has created three classes of citizens—first-, second- and third-class citizens—when it comes to employees of small business.As I said at the outset, this government’s approach is that there is only one way to help small business—that is, to take something away from the employees of small business. Why doesn’t this government do something about the paperwork compliance burden for small business? Why doesn’t it do something to take the burden that it has created in relation to superannuation choice? The government has the chance to do this right now. Why doesn’t it do something to give certain small business owners the capacity to have the bargaining agent of their choice, whether it be the Cricketers Association or, heaven forbid, a registered trade union? Why doesn’t it give the small businesses of this nation that right, that choice? We hear all about choice from this government—superannuation choice, for example—but it is taking away the right to a choice for certain small businesses to have trade unions representing them in their negotiations.This government is ideologically confused but ideologically hell-bent on taking away the rights of employees of small business. This is an illogical, unfair and ideologically driven system that lets down Australian workers, lets down small businesses and lets down the economy generally. I call on the House to support Labor’s amendment and I call on the House to take a sensible, well-measured, reasoned approach and reject this government’s extreme ideological agenda.

name: Ciobo, Steven, MP
content: —I am pleased to rise to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004.This bill amends the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to maintain the exemption that exists for small business from redundancy pay by overturning the recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission imposing redundancy pay obligations on small businesses. I am pleased, as a representative for the seat of Moncrieff, which on a per capita basis is the small business capital of Australia, to associate myself with the very good benefits that will flow and will continue to flow to small business as a consequence of the enactment of this bill.It is interesting for me to follow the member for Prospect and the remarks that the Labor Party have made in this debate. It has been interesting to hear the Australian Labor Party come into this chamber and argue in some confused way that they in fact are the friends of small business. They argue that they are the friends of small business by enforcing very harsh obligations, in many instances, on the small business sector. Nothing could be further from the truth.I heard the member for Prospect remark that it is up to the Howard federal government to justify the various propositions that we are putting forward in reforms to industrial relations and the need that we see to maintain the exemption for small business from redundancy pay. I also heard the member for Prospect claim that it is an ideologically confused Liberal Party and an ideologically confused National Party that are sending mixed signals to the Australian work force and Australian small business owners about what we see as the best way forward for this sector. It is interesting that the member for Prospect and the Australian Labor Party would argue that in this particular bill it is the Howard government that is ideologically confused.It is interesting because, when the test case was put before the AIRC in this particular instance, the state Labor governments did not support having redundancy pay imposed on small business. State Labor governments adopted a contrary point of view to that which the member for Prospect and other Labor members have put forward in this debate this evening. Let there be no doubt that there is only one political party that is confused when it comes to what is necessary to continue the growth of employment and small businesses in Australia, ensure the profitability of small businesses and, most importantly, provide the necessary conditions for a flexible work force for small businesses so that they can provide one of their most overriding concerns—that is, employment opportunities for Australians. After all, it is almost a cliche now when we say that the small business sector is the engine room of the Australian economy.I am very pleased to speak on behalf of small businesses in my electorate of Moncrieff and in Gold Coast City, and to argue for a continued exemption for those small businesses from the burden of redundancy pay. I recognise that an exemption for small businesses from redundancy pay may have possible ramifications for an employee. But I am reminded that, if a small business becomes insolvent, then there is nothing for the employee at all. Far be it from us to say, ‘We’ll impose a redundancy pay obligation on you’—which may be a contributing factor to the eventual insolvency of a business. There will be nothing for the employee then.The crocodile tears from the Australian Labor Party about how harshly this government treats employees could not be further from the truth. This government is committed to ensuring the right economic conditions through strong economic management, the right conditions to employ a productive work force and, most importantly, that the impossible shackles that Labor Party policy would impose on future employment are not imposed, so that small businesses will actively go about employing Australians, giving them a chance and providing them with a pay packet which, fundamentally, is a key concern.I have always rallied behind local businesses on the Gold Coast and I am not about to stop. My wife is involved in small business and I come from a small business family. I continue to stand up in this chamber and speak on behalf of small businesses. Many small businesses simply cannot afford large redundancy payouts. There are now some 1.6 million small businesses operating in Australia and, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, their annual profit is approximately $32,000 per business.This recent decision by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will impose unreasonable financial burdens on small business. For example, a typical retail small business with, say, seven employees, each with six years continuous employment, would face a contingent liability for redundancy pay of nearly $30,000. There are reasonable grounds to assume that the bill will have potential influence over the redundancy entitlements of some one million small business employees, on the assumption that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission’s redundancy decision potentially broadened access to the redundancy pay entitlement.I recognise that, for those one million potential small business employees, it could be construed as a negative. But the point that I will stress, and the more important point, is that if these kinds of exemptions are not provided to small businesses—small businesses with an average profit of some $32,000 per annum—people will not be employed to begin with. As I said earlier, if a business becomes insolvent, then people would not have the opportunity to receive many of their entitlements, let alone their redundancy pay entitlements.The coalition is absolutely committed to opposing unnecessary restraints on small businesses, which make it harder for them to employ people. If this bill is not passed, the vast majority of small businesses that are covered by federal awards will eventually, it is fair to say, be subjected to providing redundancy payments for their employees in accordance with the AIRC decision. It is likely that this decision will also flow through to the state jurisdictions. This bill will not affect any redundancy pay provisions that were in awards prior to the AIRC decision. The AIRC has created a new entitlement which did not previously exist.It is absolutely vital that opportunities for continued growth and job creation for those 1.1 million non-agricultural small businesses in Australia continue to be maximised. It is even more essential for the 3.3 million people that are employed by these businesses. This bill in no way prevents small businesses reaching agreements with their employees to include redundancy provisions in their terms of employment. It is about preventing the imposition of a one-size-fits-all regulation which, quite frankly, many small businesses will not be able to afford. The government have been consistent and strong and I will be consistent and strong in my support for small business. We recognise that the biggest threat to jobs growth in Australia is the unnecessary impediments which make it harder for small business to employ people.This decision is fundamentally flawed because the decision the AIRC took overturned the exemption from severance pay for businesses with fewer than 15 employees. This exemption was established by the AIRC’s predecessor back in 1984, a decision which was then turned on its head. The Queensland Industrial Relations Commission recently decided that the small business exemption under the Queensland system should remain. It found that the imposition of redundancy pay obligations had ‘the very real potential to result in the insolvency of a number of small businesses.’ In 1994 the New South Wales Industrial Commission also reaffirmed the need for small business exemption. It is significant to note, as I stressed earlier, that none of the four state governments that took part in this AIRC test case supported the removal of the exemption—the Queensland and WA state Labor governments opposed the removal, while the New South Wales and Victorian Labor governments neither supported nor opposed it.Despite what the member for Prospect said earlier, the fact remains that redundancy pay provisions can be incorporated into awards if that is the decision of both parties to the award. The result is that we provide a framework which provides flexibility to small business owners and employers as well as ensuring that small business employees are in a position to also argue the merits of their case. The fundamental fact is that redundancy pay principally comes into effect at a time when a small business is having problems. There are not many small businesses that will make their staff redundant if everything is going very strongly. Typically, the reason for redundancy is the fact that a small business is encountering financial difficulties or experiencing transitions with regard to the goods or services that they provide. So there is no point in wondering what the impact would be on small businesses if at a time of financial difficulty we were to say, ‘You must meet the liability of redundancy payment to those employees who are taking redundancy.’ Can you imagine the problems that would cause?This was a flawed decision. This bill is crucial to ensuring the long-term sustainability of a flexible workplace relations system that is to the benefit of employees and employers. Most fundamentally, this bill continues to reflect the Howard government’s and my own commitment to supporting small business because it is fundamentally central to the long-term sustainability of employment and economic prosperity that all Australians enjoy. In conclusion, I highlight that this is a positive bill, good for small businesses on the Gold Coast and good for continuing employment in Australia.

name: Barresi, Phillip, MP
content: —In the brief time that I have to make a contribution in this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004, I am more than pleased to add my voice to the government’s argument its need. (Quorum formed) Like many of my colleagues on this side of the House I am more than pleased to add my voice to this bill, which protects small businesses. From the contributions of all members on this side it is evident that there is only one voice speaking out on behalf of small business, and that voice is on this side of the House and not on the other. We have the interests and the livelihoods of those who take the brave and often risky gamble of entering into a business venture of their own to heart. I know that all of us on this side certainly have made it a core concern of ours throughout this term of government, and in fact throughout the entire Howard government stewardship of this country.I too know how it feels to put all your hard earned savings on the line and to have your family wondering if it was the right move to give up your salaried position. It is only through small businesses that we truly begin the process of employment growth that so many others in the community will eventually benefit from. I welcome the opportunity to stand up and assist small business in this place. I am also proud of the fact that the coalition remains the only political voice in Australia that will vehemently oppose unnecessary restraints on small businesses, particularly when they make it harder for them to employ people. Small businesses can well do without excessive shackles being placed upon them. By voting against this bill, that is exactly what the opposition are doing! They are placing shackles upon them which have been imposed by a recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.Debate interrupted.

name: Ferguson, Laurie, MP
content: —We have heard much talk of the 60 years since the end of the Second World War. Tonight I want to talk about a person whose contribution to this country in the postwar period so epitomises the contribution to this country and to my own electorate of the Ukrainian community. My electorate has one of Australia’s greatest concentrations of Ukrainians. It has many Ukrainian community institutions, such as the Karpaty Credit Union, the Ukrainian club, the Ukrainian Catholic Church, the monastery, the women’s association hall et cetera.Johann Kwasnycia lived within 10 houses of the house I grew up in. His life epitomises the contribution of a lot of the Ukrainians in my area, families such as the Iwachiws, Baranowskis and Shymkos. In giving this speech, I will paraphrase extensively the obituary speech given by his son following Johann’s recent death. It is very interesting to read the contribution that Johann made to this country.Johann left his homeland to escape the invading Russian Army when he was only 15. When the war ended in 1945, exactly 60 years ago, Johann was working in Germany, where most had to struggle to survive under extreme food shortages. Johann continued applying to return to his homeland but was forced to stay and work in Germany.Johann and his family migrated to Australia and arrived on 11 November 1949, after six weeks of sailing in cramped ship accommodation. During the trip he worked on the boat, painting to earn a bit of extra food supply. In order to pay the fare to Australia, the family had to sign a contract to work on a farm in Tenterfield for two years. However, on arrival in Australia, they were told the contract was cancelled and they were required to be resettled in corrugated iron shelter housing at Cowra.In 1950 they moved to Kensington, Sydney, where the four lived in the rented one bedroom of a house. Life proved very difficult in Sydney, with Johann frequently walking to the city and back to find work. He eventually landed a job on the faraway Snowy Mountains hydro scheme, where he worked until the late 1950s. He often spoke of the cold and freezing conditions working there and living in Cooma. Later on, Johann was to work on a number of construction projects in Sydney, including the Eastern Suburbs railway tunnels, the Malabar treatment works and the Warragamba Dam, before moving on to the Opera House, where one of his final tasks was being suspended high in a harness gluing the large tiles onto the giant sails.Johann’s life revolved around the Ukrainian church at Lidcombe, which he attended fervently. He was extensively involved in many of the Ukrainian community’s activities. He enjoyed the company of his countrymen in a community house at Merrylands until its sale, playing cards and recalling the past. He made many donations to various Ukrainian and local charities and sent parcels and money home.Johann was a devoted family man and became a true grandfather; in Johann’s obituary, his son spoke about Johann’s many family outings. Johann tinkered endlessly under his house in his spare time. He built his own cross-cut saw, plane saw, ripper, grinder and anything else he could put together from bits he collected. He clearly passed his collection habits on to his son.In 1994 at the age of 70, following the fall of the USSR, he was finally able to go back to his home in the Ukraine to be reunited with his family, who he had not seen for 55 years. He told of the difficult conditions they still endured.Johann Kwasnycia’s life typifies the contribution of the Ukrainians in my electorate and more particularly in the suburb I come from, along with those families I mentioned earlier. In this country we have 33,000 people who say they are of Ukrainian extraction and, of those, 13,000 were actually physically born there. This community has endeavoured very strongly to maintain its Ukrainian traditions. It is increasingly difficult in second and third generations to imbue people with interest in their background and their history. To give a typical example of their continued activity, I recently attended the celebrations of the Cossack group which has toured Australia. They are very proud to say that they have been to Yulara, amongst many other places, showcasing their culture, skills and music.As I said, Johann’s life typifies the Ukrainian contribution made in my area, which essentially derived from a migrant hostel on Merrylands Road that had previously been an American hostel during the Second World War. As we celebrate 60 years since the end of the Second World War, we should also put on record the contribution of those early migration waves after the Second World War, as those migrants contributed so much to the building of this country and its diversification. Johann was typical of that contribution. (Time expired)

name: Baldwin, Robert, MP
content: —From time to time members in this House are tempted, for a variety of reasons, to change their direction in life. Recently I was asked by a very successful local company to join their progressive and dynamic team. The company is one the fastest growing businesses in the Hunter. I had the pleasure of working with them briefly prior to returning to politics in 2001. Since then I have witnessed their contribution to the development of a stronger Hunter. I am flattered that they value my abilities to make a substantial contribution to their effort and to share in their successes. I have an excellent rapport with the owners. Their direction and ideals are much in line with mine: building better opportunities for our region, creating wealth and jobs, and doing so with the utmost integrity.However, I have found that politics offers rich rewards that money cannot match. I will give two recent examples. The first was when I recently assisted a constituent, Sue Brown, to be reunited with her injured daughter Louise Barry, in London, following the train and bus bombings. The second was the smiles on the faces of the students at Dungog High School when, after their sheep were slaughtered by disturbed youths, I was able to organise replacement sheep so that their studies could continue. That is what makes the work of a politician so enjoyable and worth while. It is the reward you get from helping your constituents—a mother to be reunited with her daughter, or students to overcome a traumatic experience.I think back to why I went into politics in the first place. I did so not because I was a long-time member of the Liberal Party or an ideologue shaped by conservative icons. I came into politics because I was an angry person and had just experienced one of the most significant events in my life—the birth of our twin boys. It is an understatement to say that the birth of your children refocuses your priorities in life. In 1991, when my twin sons, Robbie and David, were born, I genuinely feared for their future. I recognised the challenges they would face and believed our country was headed in the wrong direction. Rather than complain, I accepted a challenge from a friend and decided to jump in and do something about it. I can clearly remember the evening of 5 July 1995 when I was heading out to a Liberal Party ‘meet the candidate’ function for the Paterson preselection. My then four-year-old son asked me, ‘Daddy, why are you going out tonight? Can’t you stay home?’ I told him that I was going out for him and that in a few years he would understand why.Over the time I have been in parliament, I have spent a lot of time discussing the issues of time management, reason and direction with my family. Like others in this chamber, my family do understand—sometimes with difficulty—encourage and wholeheartedly support my decision to represent the people of Paterson. Their reason for doing so is simple. They support my being in this parliament to help make this country a better place. In my first speech in this House, I said:... if I can be remembered for one contribution to this House I would want it to be that I was part of the team that helped turn the ship around; to steer a new course towards the nation’s salvation.Today, when I look into the eyes of my children, I know that there is still a lot of work to do to provide them and others like them with the opportunities that I and many in this House enjoyed as young Australians. When asked what drives my passion to be in parliament, I say that it is best summarised as my family and my nation. I forever ask myself what the future holds for the people of Paterson, those I represent and care about. My place is in this parliament representing them. Accordingly, I have advised the company that I cannot accept their kind offer. I am determined to do whatever I can to make this nation a better place and to provide opportunity, hope and leadership for our children.
Speaker: N/A

name: Hayes, Chris, MP
content: —Last Wednesday I had the opportunity to meet with maintenance engineers from Newcastle who are the subject of industrial action being taken by their employer, Boeing. This is not the first time that this matter has been drawn to the attention of the parliament and I am sure that it will not be the last. In rising to lend my support to the engineers at Williamstown, I acknowledge the hard work of the member for Newcastle in standing up for the rights of these workers, including their right to be represented by the Australian Workers Union.This dispute goes to the heart of concerns that working Australians have about the government’s industrial relations agenda. This is more than a dispute between a group of employees and their employer. The engineers at Williamstown have already had a taste of what is to come from the government’s industrial relations agenda, as for the last four years they have been on individual contracts. They are not simply taking a stand against the notion of being on contracts. They have tried it, have found that it does not work for them and have decided that they would prefer to be under a collective agreement. Being on individual contracts, they have found that every time the company makes a change in policy or procedure it fundamentally and unilaterally changes their conditions of employment.I am sure that everyone was relieved to hear the Prime Minister’s views on the matter last week when, in response to a question from the Leader of the Opposition, he said:….the existing law means that the company is within its rights in taking the position it is taking. It is fair and proper, under the existing law.Everyone would have been relieved by that answer, as it gives some insight into the future of industrial relations—at least in the way John Howard sees it. So much for assurances that employees will have a choice. The minister keeps reminding the House that workers will be able to elect to be on an AWA or, if they wish, they may negotiate collectively and, indeed, through a union. However, that is not the case for these employees at Boeing.The Prime Minister continues to refuse to guarantee that workers will not be worse off. He maintains that his record is his guarantee. I have to say that people are starting to treat his record in this regard very sceptically. We have an example right here and now at Newcastle. Boeing has been in Australia for a while and knows the industrial relations system. It has no qualms in having its employees at Bankstown under a collective agreement with the AWU as the principal respondent, but it is another story at its Williamstown site. We understand that the company is quite adept in reading between the lines, particularly when it comes to currying favour with the Howard government.In fairness, what better way to maintain the inside track when eyeing off Australian Defence Force contracts than to embrace the government’s Holy Grail: the Prime Minister’s personal ambition for the past 30 years to have workers forced onto individual contracts. It is difficult to look at this dispute in any other way. Boeing workers at Bankstown, as I said earlier, are happily ensconced on a certified collective agreement, while the workers at Williamstown are locked out because of the company’s insistence that they be on Australian workplace agreements. Either the company is suffering industrial schizophrenia or it is displaying gross corporate hypocrisy at levels not seen before in this country. Some might even go so far as to suggest that Boeing is simply sucking up to the government to prove its loyalty and improve its standing.There has always been a resolution available for this dispute. The employees at Williamstown agreed previously to have all of their claims heard and determined on their merits by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the country’s peak industrial umpire. These are not militant people. The majority are former RAAF personnel who have served their time protecting this country. The last thing they want is to be involved in an industrial dispute. They are skilled engineers who look after our fleet of FA18 fighters and all they want is a fair go. Interestingly, Boeing has opposed the intervention of the industrial umpire and has shown its preparedness to starve its employees—these former servicemen—and their families into submission. I wonder what this company really believes when it thinks of its employees, their families and the community. Does this famous American icon see its workers only as units of production? (Time expired)

name: Turnbull, Malcolm, MP
content: —Yesterday the Israeli defence forces began supervising the final withdrawal of Jewish settlements from the Gaza Strip. Many of these settlements have been home to Jews for more than 30 years. It came as no surprise that there is enormous sadness about this withdrawal on the part of the Israeli people, nor can it come as a surprise that many Israelis have opposed the withdrawal—vigorously, but so far without violence. Long may that be so. Traditionally, victors do not surrender land to those they have defeated. Israel occupied the Gaza Strip from Egypt after its successful defence against attack from its neighbours in 1967. Now it is withdrawing from those last parts of the Gaza Strip upon which it built settlements. It is not receiving anything in return; this is a unilateral withdrawal.The pragmatic justification made by Ariel Sharon is simply that Israel cannot maintain settlements in areas which are overwhelmingly populated by Arabs. There are about 1.4 million Palestinians in Gaza and just 8,500 Jews. The cost of defending the settlements is $US560 million each year. It is better to consolidate in those areas where the Jews are a majority. This is an about-face for Sharon, often known as the father of the settlement movement, and a reminder of the wisdom of Moshe Dayan’s reproach to those Israelis flushed with victory after 1967 who thought of a greater Israel from Jordan to the sea: ‘You want the dowry,’ he said, ‘but you do not want to marry the bride.’But the opponents of the withdrawal say that this is a capitulation to terror. It will be seen as a victory for the violent, a win for Hamas and a confirmation that Israel will continue to retreat in the face of a terror campaign that has been waged against it. They cite Sharon’s earlier claims that a withdrawal is not a recipe for peace but a recipe for war. Many observers watching the demonstrations with thousands of Jews flying their orange flags of protest will conclude that it is Sharon and Israel that have most at risk. I beg to differ. If the withdrawal results in no diminution of terrorism, if it results in a Hamas controlled Gaza being the source of further attacks against Israel, then the Israeli defence forces have the capacity to respond decisively. Sharon said yesterday, in a nationwide address, ‘If they choose fire, we will respond with fire, more severe than ever.’But, most importantly, if this unilateral withdrawal is rewarded with violence, Israel’s complaint that there is no partner for peace will be confirmed. The world will have seen Israel go through the most agonising and demoralising internal struggle as it withdrew from Gaza. It will have seen how difficult—nearly impossible—it was even for a leader like Sharon to complete that withdrawal. Then, if after all that, the critics of withdrawal are confirmed—if, after all that, withdrawal is a recipe for more violence, not peace—how can the world continue to pressure the Israelis to cede more territory? On the other hand, if all our prayers are fulfilled and the withdrawal does succeed in creating a new level of trust and the end, or perhaps the beginning of the end, of violence, then all the people of Israel and the Palestinian territories will be winners, as we will all be.Prime Minister Sharon is as tough and as shrewd as they come. He knows what he is playing for. One outcome least sought but most likely is that the withdrawal does nothing to diminish the level of terror, but it will certainly make Israel’s borders somewhat easier and much cheaper to defend. It will give Israel a powerful moral argument to use to resist further concessions. The other outcome most sought but less likely is that it will be the beginning of peace. Abu Mazen and the Palestinians have the most at risk in this game. It can be the renewal of a peace process or it can be the loss of considerable moral capital in the eyes of the free world. So while the world focuses on Sharon and Israel, it is the player on the other side of the chessboard who has the most challenging moves to make and the most to win or lose. Sharon is putting the ball in Abu Mazen’s court—he cannot afford to drop it.
